• The current cosmological model, known as the concordance model, is based on the assumption that dark energy (de) and dark matter (dm) are separate components, but recent observations suggest that they may be interacting. The interaction between de and dm could solve the coincidence problem, which is the question of why the current value of the de density is so close to the critical density. The interaction could also alleviate the fine-tuning problem, which is the need for a very specific value of the de density to explain the observed acceleration of the universe's expansion.

• The interaction between de and dm could be tested using a variety of observations, including the cosmic microwave background (CMB), the large-scale structure of the universe, and the distribution of galaxies. The CMB is a remnant of the early universe and contains information about the universe's density and composition. The large-scale structure of the universe is the distribution of galaxies and galaxy clusters, which can be used to test the properties of de and dm.

• The Planck satellite and other CMB experiments have provided precise measurements of the CMB, which can be used to test the concordance model and search for evidence of de and dm interactions. The Planck satellite observed the microwave and sub-millimeter sky from 2009 to 2013 and produced maps of the CMB in temperature and polarization. The CMB data can be used to constrain the properties of de and dm and test the concordance model.

• Future experiments, such as the Square Kilometre Array (SKA) and the Large Synoptic Survey Telescope (LSST), will provide even more precise measurements of the CMB and the large-scale structure of the universe. The SKA will be a radio telescope that will observe the universe in unprecedented detail and will be able to detect the faint signals of de and dm interactions. The LSST will be a telescope that will observe the universe in visible and infrared light and will be able to detect the distribution of galaxies and galaxy clusters with unprecedented precision.

• The color superconducting phase can exist in the central region of compact stars, and the charge neutrality condition and equilibrium are required to form bulk matter inside compact stars.
• The mismatch between the Fermi surfaces of the pairing quarks can induce chromomagnetic instabilities in the color superconducting phase.
• The g2sc phase is a gapless phase that can exist at moderate baryon densities, and it is characterized by a gapless 2sc phase or a gapless CFL phase.
• The g2sc phase can exhibit chromomagnetic instabilities, including the instability of off-diagonal gluons and the instability of the 8th gluon.
• The instability of the 8th gluon can be cured by the condensation of off-diagonal gluons, but the instability of off-diagonal gluons cannot be cured by the condensation of off-diagonal gluons.
• The study of the instability driven by mismatch is important for understanding the behavior of QCD at finite baryon density and the properties of compact stars.

* The melting phase transition of two-dimensional (2D) systems has been a topic of debate for several decades, with different theories and simulations yielding conflicting results. The Kosterlitz-Thouless-Halperin-Nelson-Young (KTHNY) theory is a widely accepted theory that describes the transition as a two-stage process, but it has been criticized for assuming a dilute and unstructured distribution of lattice defects. Recent studies have shown that the KTHNY theory may not be applicable to all systems, and that the hexatic phase may not be a stable phase in all cases.
* The authors of this study have performed extensive microcanonical molecular dynamics simulations of a 2D system with a Yukawa potential to investigate the melting phase transition. They found that the velocity distribution function relaxes rapidly, but the configurational temperature and long-range correlations relax much more slowly, and that the relaxation times depend strongly on the temperature and system size. The authors conclude that increasing the system size alone is insufficient to achieve equilibrium, and that the length of the equilibration period is crucial in determining the properties of the system.

• The Kepler mission has discovered over 4,000 planetary candidates in 3,200 systems, with many of these systems being multiple star systems.
• The assumption that all stars are single stars can lead to a systematic underestimate of planetary radii, with a mean correction factor of 1.5.
• The correction factor depends on the stellar temperature of the host star, with hotter stars having a smaller range of possible stellar companions.
• The Kepler mission has funded a substantial ground-based follow-up observation program, including radial velocity vetting and high-resolution imaging.
• The radial velocity vetting can detect companions with orbital periods of up to 2 years, while high-resolution imaging can detect companions with separations of up to 0.1 arcseconds.
• The fraction of undetected companions is estimated to be around 46% for the Kepler stars, but can be reduced to around 15% for stars that are vetted with radial velocity and high-resolution imaging.
• The mean correction factor for vetted stars is around 1.2, which is significantly lower than the unvetted value of 1.5.
• The mean correction factor for vetted K2 and TESS stars is even lower, around 1.05, due to the increased effectiveness of high-resolution imaging at closer distances.
• The occurrence rates of Earth-sized planets may be affected by the amplitude of the uncertainties resulting from undetected companions.
• A Monte Carlo simulation has been performed to assign randomly the effect of unseen companions on the Kepler stars, with the results showing that the correction factors can have a significant impact on the derived occurrence rates of Earth-sized planets.</summary>

• The formation of stars in star clusters is thought to occur through the collapse and fragmentation of giant molecular clouds. The resulting clusters are initially composed of a combination of gas and stars, but the gas is eventually removed through stellar winds and supernovae explosions. This process can cause the cluster to become out of equilibrium, leading to the loss of gas and the formation of a bound core.

• The dynamical state of young star clusters is often assumed to be in virial equilibrium, but this assumption may not always be valid. The removal of gas can cause the cluster to become out of equilibrium, leading to the loss of stars and the formation of a tail of stars that are no longer bound to the cluster.

• The surface brightness profiles of young star clusters can be used to study their dynamical state. The profiles of three young massive star clusters, M82-F, NGC 1569-A, and NGC 1705-1, show an excess of light at large radii, indicating that they are not in virial equilibrium.

• Simulations of the effects of gas expulsion on massive young clusters produce similar surface brightness profiles, suggesting that gas expulsion is a key factor in the evolution of these clusters. The simulations also show that the virial mass estimates of these clusters can be significantly wrong for several tens of millions of years.

• The observations and simulations suggest that gas expulsion is an important phase in the evolution of young star clusters, and that claims of unusual initial mass functions (IMFs) for these clusters may be in error. The clusters are not in virial equilibrium, and the assumption of virial equilibrium may not be valid.

• The rapid removal of gas can cause the cluster to become out of equilibrium, leading to the loss of stars and the formation of a tail of stars that are no longer bound to the cluster. This process can also cause the cluster to become unbound and dissolve over time.

• The observations and simulations presented in this paper support the idea that gas expulsion is an important factor in the evolution of young star clusters, and that the assumption of virial equilibrium may not always be valid. Further studies are needed to better understand the dynamics of these clusters and the role of gas expulsion in their evolution.

* The transition from a liquid to an amorphous solid, also known as the glass transition, is a complex problem in statistical physics. The glass transition is characterized by a sharp increase in the characteristic relaxation times of the system and a departure from equilibrium. The transition is often associated with a thermodynamic equilibrium transition, where the system undergoes a phase transition from a liquid to a glassy state.
* The mode-coupling theory (MCT) is a theoretical framework that attempts to explain the glass transition. The MCT predicts that the transition occurs when the system's density fluctuations become arrested, leading to a non-ergodic state. The theory also predicts that the transition is triggered by an underlying thermodynamic equilibrium transition.
* The MCT has been applied to various systems, including binary mixtures of transition metals. The theory has been successful in predicting the glass transition temperature (Tg) of these systems, but the results are sensitive to the choice of model parameters.
* The authors of this paper have performed molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of a binary mixture of nickel and zirconium (Ni-Zr) to study the glass transition. The simulations were performed using a model that includes the electron theoretical description of the interatomic potentials for transition metal alloys.
* The MD simulations were used to calculate the partial structure factors, partial correlation functions, and non-ergodicity parameters of the system. The results show that the system exhibits a glass transition at a temperature of around 1005 K.
* The authors also calculated the diffusion coefficients of the Ni and Zr atoms in the system. The results show that the diffusion coefficients follow a critical power law above the glass transition temperature, with a non-universal exponent.
* The authors estimated the glass transition temperature (Tg) from the diffusion coefficients and found a value of around 850-900 K. This value is lower than the value estimated from the non-ergodicity parameters, which is around 1005 K.
* The authors conclude that the glass transition temperature is sensitive to the choice of model parameters and the method used to estimate Tg. They also note that the results are consistent with previous studies of other glass-forming systems.
* The authors suggest that the glass transition is a complex phenomenon that is influenced by many factors, including the choice of model parameters, the method used to estimate Tg, and the properties of the system being studied.

• The paper proposes a Bayesian approach to analyze longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts, which is a common problem in psychosocial and behavioral studies. The approach uses a selection model to account for the nonignorable dropouts and a transition model to model the longitudinal measurement process. The model is applied to a breast cancer study, where the goal is to understand the interdependence of patients and their spouses regarding their depression experience. The study finds that the patients and spouses are highly interdependent and influence each other's depression status.

• The proposed approach is compared to the complete-case and available-case analyses, which are common methods for handling missing data. The results show that the proposed approach outperforms the other two methods in terms of bias and coverage rates. The complete-case analysis is invalid and leads to biased estimates and poor coverage rates, while the available-case analysis yields unbiased estimates but may not account for the nonignorable dropouts.

• The paper also conducts two simulation studies to evaluate the performance of the proposed method. The first simulation study shows that the proposed method yields unbiased estimates and reasonable coverage rates when the missing data are nonignorable. The second simulation study demonstrates that the method is robust to misspecification of the dropout model.

• The paper applies the proposed method to a breast cancer study, which finds significant "partner" effects for both patients and spouses. The "actor" effects for the patients and spouses are also significant, indicating that the depression of each individual is correlated with their own previous CESD scores.

• The study also finds that the missing data for the patients are nonignorable, as the probability of dropout is significantly associated with the patient's current (missing) CESD score. In contrast, the missing data for the spouse appear to be ignorable.

• The paper highlights the importance of accounting for nonignorable dropouts in longitudinal dyadic data analysis. Ignoring the nonignorable dropouts can lead to a failure to detect important covariate effects and biased estimates.

• The proposed approach provides a flexible and robust method for analyzing longitudinal dyadic data with nonignorable dropouts. The method can be applied to various fields, including psychosocial and behavioral studies, and can provide valuable insights into the interdependence of individuals in dyadic relationships.

• The paper proposes a holistic immunity system to prevent active P2P worms from spreading in unstructured P2P overlay networks. The system consists of internal defense and external protection mechanisms to detect, isolate, and patch infected hosts.
• The internal defense mechanism uses phagocytes, which are elected among participating P2P hosts, to monitor and detect infected hosts, isolate them, and propagate alerts to other phagocytes. The phagocytes also perform software patching to distribute patches to managed hosts.
• The external protection mechanism uses an adaptive and interaction-based computational puzzle scheme to filter requests from external hosts and prevent them from attacking the P2P overlay. The puzzle scheme adjusts its difficulty level based on the real-time statuses of the network environment.
• The system is evaluated using a massive-scale testbed with realistic network traces from a million-node Gnutella network. The performance is characterized by three metrics: peak infection percentage, blowup factor of latency, and percentage of successful external attacks.
• The results show that the system can effectively prevent internal attacks and external attacks, and the phagocytes can efficiently filter requests from external hosts to the P2P overlay while minimizing latency and packet loss.

• The debris disk system around HD 32297 is an intermediate stage of stellar system evolution, representing the transition between the early formation of stars and planets and the mature stage of an evolved system. The disk has lost most of its primordial material, but the observed infrared luminosity of circumstellar dust is several orders of magnitude larger than estimated for the Kuiper and asteroid belts in our solar system. The disk is edge-on, making it an ideal target for gas phase absorption measurements.

• The authors observed the D2 line of Ca II toward HD 32297 and several nearby stars, using the Coudé spectrograph on the 2.7m Harlan J. Smith Telescope at McDonald Observatory. The observations were made over several epochs, with a resolution of 7240.

• Two absorption components are detected toward HD 32297, while only one is detected toward its proximate neighbors located at a comparable distance. The extra absorption component in the spectrum of HD 32297 is likely caused by circumstellar material.

• The interstellar medium (ISM) absorption is similar among HD 32297 and its two closest neighbors, and is likely due to absorption from the shell that defines the boundary of the local bubble. Some variation in local bubble absorption is detected toward 18 Ori.

• The radial velocities of HD 32297, BD+07 777s, and BD+07 778 are measured and differ significantly, indicating that they are likely not physically associated.

• Some indication of temporal variability is detected over several epochs of observations, with the redshifted variability seen between 2005 September and 2006 February being 4.5σ above the standard deviation.

• The measured circumstellar feature toward HD 32297 is the strongest such absorption measured toward any nearby main sequence debris disk, 45 times greater than the column density of the prototypical edge-on debris disk, HD 139614.

• The authors estimate an upper limit to the gas mass in the circumstellar disk surrounding HD 32297 of 40.3+5.0 M⊕, assuming the morphology and abundances of the stable gas component around HD 32297 are similar to those of HD 139614.

The rate at which these events occur in the local universe is another parameter that characterizes whether they are potential sources of gravitational waves. The authors have predicted a detection rate of one event every 125 and 148 years by initial LIGO and VIRGO respectively, and up to 6 detections per year in their advanced configurations.

The maximum probability to form a massive binary occurs at a redshift of about 0.5, while the maximum probability to occur a coalescence is around 0.1. The authors have found that a truly continuous background is formed only when sources located beyond a certain redshift are included, including 96% of all events.

This means that BBN cannot impose strict constraints on the values of the free parameters of these models.

* The text discusses the core-hole problem in graphene, which is a 2D material with a unique electronic structure. The core-hole problem arises when an electron is removed from the material, leaving behind a core hole that interacts with the remaining electrons.
* The text uses a model that is based on the one used by Langreth in the 1970s, but modified and extended to fit the problem of exciton annihilation in quantum wells. The model includes the interaction between the core hole and the electrons in the material.
* The text derives the time-dependent Green's function for the system, which is used to calculate the spectral function and the density of states for the core hole. The spectral function is the density of states for an occupied core-hole state.
* The text also derives the sudden approximation for the core-hole problem, which is used to calculate the shake-up effects in the system. The sudden approximation assumes that the core hole is created instantaneously, without allowing the electrons to relax around it.
* The text shows that the sudden approximation leads to a shift of the XPS peak towards higher kinetic energy, which is due to the relaxation energy of the electrons around the core hole.
* The text also discusses the 2D plasmon dispersion in doped graphene, which is a collective excitation of the electrons in the material. The dispersion is typical of 2D plasmons and is similar for any finite doping density.
* The text concludes by generalizing the result to include all excitation processes in the system, using the boson propagator and the dynamical structure factor to describe the interactions between the core hole and the electrons.

* The phase-field method has become the method of choice for simulating microstructure formation during solidification due to its algorithmic simplicity.
* The phase-field model is rooted in the mean-field description of spatially diffuse interfaces by order parameters, but needs to bridge the scale gap between the physical solid-liquid interfaces and the typical scale of microstructures.
* The phase-field equations can be analyzed and related to the sharp-interface solution by the method of matched asymptotic expansions in the limit where the interface thickness is much smaller than the diffusion length.
* There are two independent thin-interface effects: one proportional to the interface velocity and one proportional to the current crossing the interface.
* The authors have recognized the importance of the current crossing the interface and have developed generalised expressions for the antitrapping current with coefficients that depend on the value of the current.
* Orientation-field models have been developed to describe the evolution of polycrystals during solidification, but the equation of motion for the orientation field is incorrect for coherent crystalline matter.
* The evolution of the orientation field is linked to the motion of dislocations, which is a difficult task due to the complicated elastic interactions and external strain.
* The phase-field models make predictions that are qualitatively wrong, such as the decrease of misorientation with time, which is inconsistent with the geometrical constraints.
* The inclusion of fluctuations in the phase-field equations is a common approach to trigger instabilities or create disorder in the geometry of microstructures, but the role of fluctuations has been investigated more quantitatively in connection with the formation of sidebranches in free dendritic growth.

• The fundamental atmospheric parameters of stars, such as effective temperature, surface gravity, and metallicity, are crucial for understanding the properties of stars and the structure of galaxies. The authors of this paper present a new method for determining these parameters using spectroscopic data from the RAVE survey. The method involves using the excitation and ionization balance of iron lines to determine the atmospheric parameters.

• The authors use a combination of 1D hydrostatic model atmospheres and NLTE (non-local thermodynamic equilibrium) calculations to determine the atmospheric parameters. They also use the Balmer lines to determine the effective temperature of the stars. The authors find that the NLTE corrections are necessary to accurately determine the atmospheric parameters.

• The authors compare their results to those obtained using the LTE (local thermodynamic equilibrium) method and find significant systematic biases in the LTE results. The biases increase with decreasing metallicity, and can be as large as 200-400 K in effective temperature, 0.5-1.5 dex in surface gravity, and 0.1-0.5 dex in metallicity.

• The authors also find that the NLTE effects on the ionization balance of iron lines are necessary to eliminate the discrepancy between the abundance of iron from Fe I and Fe II lines. The NLTE corrections are found to be significant, especially for metal-poor stars.

• The authors use a sample of 142 stars from the RAVE survey to test their method. They find that the NLTE method provides more accurate atmospheric parameters than the LTE method, and that the NLTE corrections are necessary to accurately determine the atmospheric parameters.

• The authors conclude that the NLTE method is a more accurate and reliable way to determine the atmospheric parameters of stars, especially for metal-poor stars. They also note that the NLTE corrections are necessary to accurately determine the atmospheric parameters, and that the LTE method is not sufficient for this purpose.

• The authors suggest that the NLTE method can be used to study the chemical and dynamical properties of the Milky Way and other galaxies, and that it can provide a more accurate understanding of the properties of stars and the structure of galaxies.

• The authors investigate the relationship between the magnitude of type Ia supernovae (SNe) and the number of galaxies in the foreground, which could be indicative of weak gravitational lensing. They use a sample of 55 SNe with known distances and magnitudes, and find a significant anti-correlation between the two variables. The authors suggest that this correlation could be due to weak lensing, where the light from the SNe is amplified by the gravitational field of foreground galaxies.

• The authors use a simple lensing model to simulate the expected relationship between the magnitude of SNe and the number of galaxies in the foreground. They find that the model reproduces the observed correlation, and that the best-fit slope of the relationship is consistent with the expected value for weak lensing.

• The authors also explore the effect of different mass distribution models on the relationship between the magnitude of SNe and the number of galaxies in the foreground. They find that the standard mass distribution model of the universe is consistent with the observed correlation, but that more extreme models can also reproduce the data.

• The authors use a Monte Carlo simulation to generate synthetic realizations of the 50-source SN sample, and find that the observed correlation is reproduced in a significant fraction of the realizations. They also find that the probability of reproducing the correlation depends on the assumed optical depth of the universe.

• The authors investigate the effect of biasing on the relationship between the magnitude of SNe and the number of galaxies in the foreground. They find that the biasing parameters have little impact on the correlation, and that the shape of the contours of the correlation is determined by the observational constraints.

• The authors also explore the effect of different biasing schemes on the relationship between the magnitude of SNe and the number of galaxies in the foreground. They find that the power-law biasing scheme is consistent with the observed correlation, but that other schemes can also reproduce the data.

• The authors conclude that the observed correlation between the magnitude of SNe and the number of galaxies in the foreground is consistent with the predictions of weak lensing, and that the data can be reproduced by a simple lensing model with a standard mass distribution. They also find that the biasing parameters have little impact on the correlation, and that the shape of the contours of the correlation is determined by the observational constraints.

• The authors suggest that the observed correlation could be used to constrain models of the universe, and that future observations of SNe could provide further evidence for the presence of weak lensing

* The paper discusses the tidal interactions between a star and a planet in a binary system, focusing on the evolution of the star and its impact on the planet's orbital period. The authors consider three types of stars with masses of one, one and a half, and two solar masses, and calculate the overlap integrals and the change in orbital period for each star. The overlap integrals are a measure of the intensity of the tidal forces and play a crucial role in the physics of dynamical tides. The authors show that the overlap integrals can differ by two or more orders of magnitude for the same star with different structures during its evolution.
* The authors use the Mesa software package to model the stars and calculate the eigenfrequencies and eigenfunctions of the stellar oscillations. They also use the Runge-Kutta method to solve the differential equations and calculate the overlap integrals. The results show that the overlap integrals decrease rapidly as the star's lifetime increases, and that the absolute value of the overlap integrals increases by an order of magnitude in the high-frequency part of the spectrum. The authors also find that the overlap integrals are sensitive to the star's structure and can change significantly as the star evolves.
* The authors calculate the change in orbital period for planets with a mass of one Jupiter mass around the three types of stars. They find that all planets with an initial orbital period of 2 days or shorter will fall onto the star in the main-sequence lifetime of the star. The authors also find that the planet's orbital period decreases as the star evolves, and that the time scale of the orbital change decreases as the star begins to move off the main sequence. The authors conclude that the evolution of the star plays a crucial role in the planet's orbital evolution.
* The authors compare their results with previous studies and find that their results qualitatively agree with the previous results from Bolmont and Mathis (2016) and Penev (2012). They also note that their calculations should be made for a more accurate quantitative estimate. The authors acknowledge the contribution of P.B. Ivanov to the paper.
* The paper concludes that the tidal interactions between a star and a planet are an important area of research, and that the evolution of the star plays a crucial role in the planet's orbital evolution. The authors suggest that further studies should be conducted to better understand the dynamics of binary systems and the impact of tidal interactions on the planet's orbital period.

The authors show that the speckle contrast measured in a single speckle spot contains the same information as the contrast of the total emitted power.

• The authors extend the glassy wormlike chain (GWL) model to include inelastic deformations, allowing for the study of reversible inelastic behavior. They introduce a new parameter, the bond fraction, which represents the fraction of closed bonds in the network. The model is used to study the mechanical response of the network to a transient stretch, and the results show that the network exhibits a stiffening response followed by a softening response. The softening response is attributed to the breaking of bonds in the network.

• The authors also study the effect of the bond fraction on the mechanical properties of the network. They find that the bond fraction determines the storage modulus and loss angle of the network, and that the loss angle exhibits a strong overshoot during the softening response. The authors also find that the bond fraction affects the rate of recovery of the network after the deformation pulse. The results suggest that the bond fraction plays a crucial role in determining the mechanical properties of the network.

• The authors also study the effect of repeated deformation pulses on the mechanical properties of the network. They find that the force-displacement curve for the second stretching is less steep than for the first stretching, indicating a cyclic softening or viscoelastic shake-down effect. The strength of the shake-down depends on the fraction of transiently broken bonds, and the authors find that the force-displacement curve settles on a limit-curve that is preconditioned by the initial deformation pulse and the inelastic work it performed on the sample. The results suggest that the network exhibits a gradual shake-down that converges to a limit-curve after many cycles.

* *The authors study the realization of topological Mott insulators (TMIs) in electronic systems on a honeycomb lattice using mean-field calculations and Monte Carlo methods.* They find that the CDW of the 6-sublattice unit cell is more stable than previously estimated CDWs with smaller unit cells.
* *The authors show that the fermi velocity at the Dirac point needs to be suppressed to stabilize the TMI.* This is achieved by introducing third-neighbor hopping and tuning the fermi velocity to zero.
* *The authors propose that bilayer graphene with a rotation angle of 67 degrees (ab-stacking bilayer graphene) can mimic the quadratic band crossing.* This can be used to control the stability of the TMI.
* *The authors find that the CDW phase is more stable than the TMI phase in the mean-field approximation.* However, the Monte Carlo method shows that the TMI phase can be stabilized by modulating the fermi velocity.
* *The authors estimate the single-particle excitation gap induced by the TMI.* They find that the gap is substantial, up to 0.1 eV, which is larger than room temperature.
* *The authors suggest that the TMI phase can be realized in real materials such as bilayer graphene.* They propose that the fermi velocity can be controlled by changing the rotation angle between the two layers.
* *The authors note that further analysis is needed to experimentally control the stability of the TMI and to make quantitative estimates of the stability for bilayer graphenes.* They also mention that the computational materials science initiative (CMSI) and the strategic programs for innovative research (SPIRE) supported their research.

* The authors predict that the naturally occurring tilt boundaries in gated multi-layer graphene systems will host topologically protected gapless modes of transport, which can explain the observed sub-gap transport. This prediction is based on the existence of gapless edge states at the tilt boundaries, which are protected by three symmetries: time (valley) reversal, no-valley-mixing, and electron number conservation.
* The authors use a tight-binding model and first-principles calculations to demonstrate the existence of gapless edge states at the tilt boundaries, and show that these states are robust against strain and finite width effects. They also discuss the symmetry protection of the edge states and the consequences of symmetry changes within the framework of symmetry-protected topological (SPT) phases.
* The authors classify the 2D topological phase supporting the edge states, namely the quantum valley Hall (QVH) phase, among various topological insulator/superconductor phases, and show that it is distinct from previously postulated phases such as the quantum anomalous Hall (QAH), layer antiferromagnetic (LAF), and quantum spin Hall (QSH) phases.
* The authors propose several experiments to test their prediction, including four-terminal transport measurements, scanning tunneling spectroscopy, thermopower imaging, and scanning SQUID experiments, which can confirm the origin of the sub-gap transport and enable device applications of gated multi-layer graphene systems.

• The text discusses the properties of charged polymers, including polyelectrolytes and polyampholytes, which are macromolecules containing ionizable groups that dissociate in polar solvents. These polymers have numerous industrial and medical applications, and their properties are influenced by the sequence of charged monomers along the chain.

• Polyelectrolytes contain a single sign of charged monomers, while polyampholytes bear charged monomers of both signs. The properties of polyampholytes depend on the sequence of charged monomers and the bending energy of the chains.

• The text presents the results of molecular dynamics (MD) simulations of planar brushes of flexible, semiflexible, and rodlike diblock polyampholytes. The simulations show that the average brush thickness is a linear function of the grafting density, regardless of the bending energy of the chains.

• The simulations also show that the histograms of equilibrium conformations of the brushes are different for the three types of chains, with semiflexible and rodlike chains exhibiting strong dependence on the grafting density and separation of the chains into two coexisting fractions at high grafting densities.

• The text presents a simple scaling theory to describe the linear dependence of the brush thickness on the grafting density, which is applicable to the brush of flexible diblock polyampholytes. The scaling theory is based on the concept of correlation blobs and the idea that the brush is a melt of these blobs.

• The scaling theory predicts that the brush thickness is a linear function of the grafting density, with the slope depending on the system parameters. The theory is not consistently applicable for the brush of flexible chains with high grafting densities, as the range of grafting densities used in the simulations is higher than the validity range of the condition.

• The text concludes that the linear dependence of the average brush thickness on the grafting density is a general feature of polyampholyte brushes, regardless of the flexibility of the chains. The results of the simulations and the scaling theory provide insights into the properties of polyampholyte brushes and their potential applications in various fields.

* The light flavor scalar mesons are a remarkable exception to the naive quark model, and their structures have not been unambiguously determined yet. The numerous candidates below 1.5 GeV cannot be accommodated in one nonet, and some are supposed to be glueballs, molecular states, or tetraquark states. The strong attractions between diquark states in relative S-wave may result in a nonet tetraquark state manifest below 1.5 GeV. The conventional scalar mesons have masses around 1.3 GeV, and the well-established scalar and vector nonets with isospin 1/2 and 3/2 lie in the same region.
* The article constructs the color-singlet tetraquark currents with scalar diquark fields and parameterizes the nonperturbative effects with new vacuum condensates besides the gluon condensate. The new qcd sum rules are derived for the nonet scalar mesons below 1.5 GeV. The interpolating currents are constructed from the basic diquark fields instead of quark and gluon fields.
* The two-point correlation functions are written as a sum of pole terms and continuum states, and the hadronic representation is obtained by inserting a complete set of intermediate hadronic states. The ground state contributions are isolated from the pole terms of the nonet scalar mesons. The results are obtained by taking the dualities below the thresholds and performing the Borel transform with respect to the variable s.
* The threshold parameters are different from the corresponding values in eq. (6) because some QCD interactions are absorbed into the effective diquark masses. The diquark condensates play a special role in relating with the masses and decay constants of the light pseudoscalar mesons through the Gell-Mann-Oakes-Renner relation.
* The convergence behavior of the operator product expansion is very good, and the contributions from different terms have the hierarchy: perturbative term, condensate term, and higher-dimensional term. The perturbative continuum is suppressed by a factor, and the contributions from pole terms are very large.
* The scalar tetraquark currents may have non-vanishing couplings with scattering states, and the intermediate meson loops contribute a self-energy to the scalar meson. The scalar mesons below 1.5 GeV can be generated dynamically from the unitarized scattering amplitudes of pseudoscalar mesons.

* The paper discusses the application of pseudo-transient continuation (PTC) method in power system long-term stability analysis, which is an important approach for power system dynamic analysis. PTC is a theoretical-based numerical method that can be implemented directly in the long-term stability model to accelerate simulation speed.
* The long-term stability model includes different components, each requiring several differential and algebraic equations (DAE) to represent, and involves different time scales from milliseconds to minutes. The total number of DAE can be large and complex, making time-domain simulation over long time intervals expensive.
* The paper proposes a modified PTC method for the long-term stability model and the quasi-steady-state (QSS) model, which can overcome numerical difficulties and provide correct approximations. The modified PTC method is implemented in the long-term stability model and the QSS model, respectively.
* The paper presents three numerical examples to demonstrate the feasibility of the modified PTC method. The first two examples are the same 145-bus system, where the QSS model met numerical difficulties, and the modified PTC method was implemented to overcome the difficulties.
* The third example is a 14-bus system that is long-term unstable due to wild oscillations of fast variables. The modified PTC method was able to capture the instabilities of the long-term stability model.
* The paper concludes that the modified PTC method can be regarded as a good in-between method with respect to integration and steady-state calculation, and serves as an alternative method in power system long-term stability analysis.
* The paper also acknowledges the support of the Consortium for Electric Reliability Technology Solutions provided by the U.S. Department of Energy.

* The problem of anisotropic quantum scattering in two spatial dimensions (2D) has attracted increasing interest in recent years, stimulated by proposals for creating exotic and highly correlated quantum systems with dipolar gases. The recent experimental production of ultracold polar molecules in optical traps has opened up ways to realize these phenomena. The study of 2D quantum effects in condensed matter physics has a long history, including superfluid films, high-temperature superconductivity, and 2D materials like graphene. The theory of elementary quantum two-body systems and processes in the plane is also of great interest. The anisotropy and long-range character of the dipole-dipole interaction are special considerations in this field.

• The Kauffman model is a disordered dynamical system proposed by Stuart Kauffman in 1969 to study genetic regulatory systems. The model consists of a set of binary variables representing genes, which are controlled by other genes and respond to binary inputs. The system is disordered because the control rules and response functions are chosen randomly.
• The model exhibits a phase transition from a frozen phase to a chaotic phase, which is characterized by a change in the average length of the cycles and the number of attractors. The frozen phase is characterized by a small number of attractors, while the chaotic phase is characterized by a large number of attractors. The phase transition is driven by the probability of the responses to different signals being different.
• The authors study the distribution of the number of relevant elements, which are the elements that can influence the long-term behavior of the system. They find that the number of relevant elements grows exponentially with the system size in the chaotic phase, but remains constant in the frozen phase. They also find that the distribution of the relevant elements is independent of the system size in the frozen phase.
• The authors also study the magnetization of the system, which is the average activity of the elements over different initial conditions. They find that the magnetization is not a good measure of the system's behavior in the chaotic phase, but is a good measure in the frozen phase. They also find that the magnetization is not a good measure of the system's behavior in the limit of infinite system size.
• The authors propose a new method to compute the magnetization of the system, which takes into account the periodic nature of the system's behavior. They find that the new method gives a better estimate of the magnetization than the traditional method, and that the corrections to the infinite size value are large and decay exponentially with system size.

* The Kondo lattice model (KLM) is a theoretical model that describes the behavior of heavy fermion systems, which are characterized by a hierarchy of energy scales. The KLM is a many-body problem that requires a numerical solution, and the authors use the dynamical cluster approximation (DCA) to study the model. The DCA is a numerical method that uses a cluster of sites to solve the model, and it is well-suited for studying the KLM because it can capture the strong correlations between the electrons and the localized moments. The authors use the DCA to study the phase diagram of the KLM and the evolution of the single-particle spectral function as a function of doping and temperature.
* The authors find that the KLM exhibits a rich phase diagram, with a paramagnetic phase at high temperatures and an antiferromagnetic phase at low temperatures. The paramagnetic phase is characterized by a large Fermi surface, while the antiferromagnetic phase is characterized by a small Fermi surface. The authors also find that the KLM exhibits a topological transition, in which the Fermi surface changes from a large to a small size as the system is doped. This transition is driven by the competition between the Kondo screening and the antiferromagnetic order.
* The authors use the DCA to study the single-particle spectral function of the KLM, and they find that it exhibits a complex structure that depends on the doping and temperature. The spectral function is characterized by a hybridized band that is formed by the interaction between the conduction electrons and the localized moments. The authors also find that the spectral function exhibits a topological transition, in which the hybridized band changes from a large to a small size as the system is doped. This transition is driven by the competition between the Kondo screening and the antiferromagnetic order.
* The authors conclude that the KLM is a complex system that exhibits a rich phase diagram and a complex single-particle spectral function. They also conclude that the DCA is a powerful tool for studying the KLM, and that it can capture the strong correlations between the electrons and the localized moments. The authors also suggest that the KLM may be relevant to the study of heavy fermion systems, and that it may provide a new perspective on the behavior of these systems.

* The r-x mode has a maximum amplitude at a certain altitude, while the l-o mode has a maximum amplitude at a higher altitude. The electric field components of the l-o mode are primarily directed along the geomagnetic field lines.

• The Zero-Range Potential (ZRP) approach was developed to widen the limits of traditional treatment by Demkov and Ostrovsky, allowing for an exact solution of the scattering problem.
• The ZRP is conventionally represented as a boundary condition on the matrix wavefunction at some point, or as a pseudopotential.
• The Darboux transformation (DT) allows for the construction of exactly solvable potentials and can be used to correct the ZRP model.
• The DT can be defined on the basis of the covariance property of the Schrödinger equation with respect to a transformation of the wavefunction and potential.
• The DT can be used to dress the ZRP, improving its possibilities, and can be applied in multi-dimensional space.
• The DT can be used to add or remove poles of the matrix, allowing for the creation of complex poles corresponding to quasi-stationary states (resonances).
• The ZRP can be used to study scattering problems, including the scattering of electrons by polyatomic molecules, and can be dressed to correct for polarization effects.
• The DT can be used to improve the agreement between calculated and experimental cross sections, particularly at higher collision energies.

The equation is solved using the differential quadrature method (DQM) with modified cubic B-splines as base functions. The DQM is an approximation method that transforms the partial differential equation into a system of ordinary differential equations, which can be solved numerically. The modified cubic B-splines are used to approximate the spatial derivatives in the equation.
• The DQM is applied to solve the convection-diffusion equation with Dirichlet and Neumann boundary conditions. The method is tested on three test problems, and the results are compared with the exact solutions. The results show that the proposed method is accurate and efficient, and the error norms are smaller than those obtained using other methods.

The results show that the method is stable for all the test problems, and the real part of each eigenvalue is either zero or negative. * The axial anomaly is a fundamental issue in quantum field theory, and it has been analyzed deeply over the years. The axial anomaly can be treated using the renormalization procedure, which gives the interpretation of its origin in terms of ultraviolet divergences. Alternatively, the axial anomaly can be analyzed using the dispersion relation method, which provides a more direct treatment and allows for the study of its infrared aspects.
* The axial anomaly is related to the non-conservation of helicity, which is a consequence of the chiral symmetry breaking. The axial anomaly can be derived by studying the properties of the amplitude in the infrared region, and it is connected to the presence of a term independent of the fermion mass in the corresponding cross sections. This term is a manifestation of the axial anomaly and corresponds to the anomalous term present in the divergence of the axial current.
* The mass singularities in the radiative pion and pi decay rates can be canceled through a mechanism that involves the combination of collinear and infrared divergences. The cancellation of mass singularities is a consequence of the degeneracy of the states in the theory with massless particles, which leads to the appearance of infrared and collinear divergences. The KLN theorem guarantees that these divergences cancel out in the total inclusive decay rate, resulting in a finite and well-defined result.

* The paper discusses the problem of salient object detection, which is the task of identifying the most important objects in an image. The authors propose a simple baseline model that consists of two steps: first, a fixation prediction model is used to find spatial outliers in the image that attract human eye movements, and then a segmentation algorithm is used to segment the image into regions that overlap with the salient regions. The model is evaluated on three datasets, including the MSRA-5k, Bruce-A, and Judd-A datasets.

They also find that the most salient objects in the Judd-A dataset are often people or text.

They use two metrics to evaluate the performance of the models: precision-recall curves and receiver operating characteristic (ROC) curves. The results show that the proposed model performs well on the Bruce-A and Judd-A datasets, but not as well on the MSRA-5k dataset.

• The CaP coatings are deposited using a sol-gel process, electro-phoretic deposition (EPD), or biomimetic deposition (BM) at room temperature, and can be combined with a continuous or discontinuous polymer coating.
• The coatings have a thickness of less than 0.001 mm and a bonding strength to the metallic substrate of greater than 40 MPa, allowing them to maintain their integrity during deformation.
• The CaP coatings can be designed to have controlled porosity and drug release properties, making them suitable for controlled release of bioactive agents.
• The invention also includes a process for preparing the CaP coatings, which involves hydrolyzing a phosphor precursor, adding a calcium salt precursor, depositing the resulting gel on the substrate, and calcining the coating at a suitable temperature.
• The CaP coatings have been shown to be highly flexible and maintain their integrity during deformation, making them suitable for use in medical implants that require deformation capability, such as coronary stents.

• The present invention provides a nerve guidance conduit (NGC) with an integrated spiral structured porous sheet decorated with surface channels and electrospun fibers, which provides superior mechanical strength and favorable conditions for nerve regeneration.
• The NGC has a three-dimensional (3-D) spiral structured porous sheet with proximal and distal reserved chambers, allowing for nerve stumps to be placed and sutured without tension.
• The spiral structure includes a highly porous polycaprolactone (PCL) sheet with interconnected pores, which can be fabricated using a combination of solvent evaporation and salt-leaching methods.
• The PCL sheet is wound in a spiral fashion to form a spiral NGC, which can be used to bridge nerve gaps of various lengths.
• The spiral NGC can be further coated with a dense layer of randomly-oriented nanofibers to provide additional mechanical strength and prevent tissue infiltration.
• The NGC can also be coated with aligned nanofibers to provide a guidance channel for nerve regeneration.
• The tensile properties of the NGCs were measured, showing that the Young's Modulus, percent elongation, and tensile strength of the NGCs were all within a useful range for use in nerve regeneration and repair.
• The NGCs were tested in a 10 mm rat sciatic nerve defect model, showing that the NGC with aligned nanofibers (T-S-AF) had significantly greater cell proliferation and improved functional recovery compared to the other groups.
• The results suggest that the NGC with aligned nanofibers can accelerate the level of muscle reinnervation and improve functional recovery in peripheral nerve regeneration.

• The present disclosure relates to a crush-resistant anvil assembly for use with a surgical stapling device, which includes an anvil shaft, an anvil head assembly, and a stabilizing collet.
• The anvil shaft has a plurality of flexible legs that define a longitudinal bore and are configured to flex outwardly in response to insertion of a trocar of the surgical stapling device.
• The stabilizing collet is received within the longitudinal bore and is positioned to prevent damage to the flexible legs during attachment of the anvil assembly to the stapling device.
• The collet is secured within the longitudinal bore by a plurality of cantilevered fingers that engage holes formed in the anvil shaft, and the trocar is received within the longitudinal bore and engages a recess defined at the proximal end of the flexible legs to secure the anvil assembly to the stapling device.
• The anvil assembly is designed to facilitate reliable attachment to the stapling device and to prevent damage to the anvil shaft during attachment, thereby ensuring proper function of the surgical stapling device.

<summary>
• The present invention is a cardiac assist system that combines a muscle stimulator and a cardiac pacer-cardioverter-defibrillator to provide cardiac assistance during cardiac arrhythmias.
• The system includes a pulse generator that senses cardiac electrical activity and detects arrhythmias, and a muscle stimulator that stimulates a skeletal muscle graft wrapped around the heart to assist cardiac contractions.
• The system has a detection interval range that distinguishes between normal sinus rhythm, ventricular tachycardia, and ventricular fibrillation, and adjusts muscle stimulation accordingly to avoid interference with arrhythmia detection.
• The system also has a second look criterion that determines whether to deliver VT or VF therapy based on the previous 8 intervals, and a VT/VF termination detection state that determines whether VT or VF is re-detected after therapy is delivered.
• The system is designed to provide rapid detection and therapy for cardiac arrhythmias while minimizing interference with muscle stimulation and ensuring safe and effective treatment.

• The invention relates to an accommodating intraocular lens (IOL) device that provides a range of accommodation and corrects for presbyopia. The IOL device has a lens chamber with opposing sides that are deformable and a base lens that is more rigid. The lens chamber is filled with a fluid or gel that has a high refractive index and low viscosity. The IOL device is designed to be implanted in the capsular bag of the eye and is intended to restore the natural range of accommodation.

• The lens chamber has a bi-convex exterior shape and an internal enclosed cavity that is filled with the fluid or gel. The opposing sides of the lens chamber have a central region and a peripheral region, with a gradient of thickness that increases radially from the peripheral region to the central region. This thickness profile is intended to encourage deformation of the opposing sides away from each other and to permit the opposing sides to bulge and increase in curvature in opposing directions along an optical axis. The central region has a thickness that is at least two times greater than the thickness of the peripheral region.

• The base lens is coupled to the lens chamber via a lens periphery and is more rigid than the opposing sides of the lens chamber. The base lens is preferably a positive lens that provides convergent power, such as a bi-convex, plano-convex, or positive meniscus lens. The base lens is designed to resist deformation and is made of a material that has a higher elastic Young's modulus than the material used for the opposing sides of the lens chamber.

• The lens periphery has a radial portion and a circumferential hinge that cooperate to transmit a significant portion of the radially compressive forces exerted onto the circumferential edge onto the lens chamber. The radial portion extends radially inwardly from the lens periphery to the lens chamber and the hinge is disposed between the lens periphery and the base lens. The circumferential hinge permits the lens periphery to pivot radially inwardly towards the lens chamber, transmitting the radially compressive forces onto the lens chamber.

• The IOL device is designed to be implanted in the capsular bag of the eye and is intended to restore the natural range of accommodation. The IOL device is made of a material that is biocompatible and has a low Young's modulus, such as a silicone polymer or a phenyl siloxane polymer. The IOL device is designed to be implanted in a relatively small incision size and is rolled up

• The invention is a continuation-in-part of a prior application and relates to esophageal electrodes, particularly an esophageal-stomach electrode that can be inserted down a patient's esophagus and into the stomach to stimulate the heart. The electrode is designed to be moved close to the heart to reduce the energy required to perform procedures such as pacing or defibrillation. The electrode includes a semi-rigid plastic tube with a mechanism to bend the distal end of the tube to displace the stomach wall and position the electrode close to the heart. The mechanism includes a pin and cords that can be manipulated to control the bending of the tube.

• The esophageal-stomach displacement electrode is designed to be used in conjunction with an external electrode placed on the patient's chest. The electrode is inserted through the mouth or nasal passage and advanced to a depth where the distal end of the tube is in the stomach. The distal end of the tube is then bent to displace the stomach wall and position the electrode close to the heart. The bending of the tube is controlled by a mechanism that includes a pin and cords.

• The mechanism for bending the tube includes a pin that is disposed in the tube and extends generally parallel to the tube axis. The pin is connected to cords that extend proximally in the tube and out of the tube to a control mechanism. The control mechanism includes a slide that can be moved to control the position of the pin in the tube.

• The control mechanism is connected to the distal ends of the cords and operates the displacement mechanism by taking up one cord and playing out the other. The control mechanism includes a sleeve and a slide that can be moved to control the position of the pin in the tube. The slide is U-shaped and has an opening that rests on the bottom wall of the sleeve.

• The electrode is typically used in a pacing mechanism, where the tube is inserted into the esophagus and advanced to a depth where the distal end of the tube is in the stomach. The distal end of the tube is then bent to displace the stomach wall and position the electrode close to the heart. The pacing pulses are then imposed across the electrodes.

• The invention provides a convenient means of enabling an operator to place the esophageal-stomach displacement electrode very close to the heart or other organ by means of a noninvasive procedure. • The game is a board game that simulates the ups and downs of life at a lake, where players acquire, sell, mortgage, and improve properties such as lake areas, boat dealerships, and dams.
• The game is played with a board featuring a continuous path with various spaces, including lake areas, boat dealerships, dams, and other lake-related spaces.
• Players move their tokens around the board based on the roll of dice, and can purchase properties from the bank or other players, with prices displayed on the associated title deed cards.
• Players can improve their lake areas by erecting lake cabins and marinas, but must do so in an even manner across the associated group of lake areas.
• The game includes various spaces that do not have corresponding title deed cards, such as Waterfront Taxes Due, Boat Tab Renewal, and FREE BOAT LAUNCH, which have specific rules and penalties.
• Players can also draw Sunken Chest or Makin A Wake cards, which can send them to jail or impose other penalties, and can be used to disrupt their opponents' progress in the game.

* The invention is a gravity-driven vehicle that can be steered and braked, allowing for precise control and maneuverability.
* The vehicle has a chassis with a rider riding surface that is inclined to allow the rider to ride in a prone, face-down position.
* The vehicle has at least two wheels or skis, and may have a combination of wheels and skis or a slide pan.
* The vehicle has a steering system that allows the rider to steer the vehicle using a handlebar or other control.
* The vehicle has a braking system that allows the rider to slow or stop the vehicle using a brake lever or other control.
* The vehicle has a suspension system that absorbs shock and provides a smooth ride over rough terrain.
* The vehicle has a low center of gravity, which provides stability and makes it difficult to tip over.
* The vehicle has a safety harness that keeps the rider secure and provides additional stability.
* The vehicle has a tow bar that allows it to be towed to the top of a hill or other incline.
* The vehicle can be retrofitted with skis or a slide pan to allow it to be used on snow-covered terrain.

<summary>
* *The present invention employs a Hilbert space inverse wave (HSIW) algorithm to reconstruct images of a medium surrounding a physical probe in a radial reflection configuration, using a linearized scattering model to form images given the physical transmitter and receiver configurations and the mathematical method utilized to invert the scattering collected fields.* The HSIW algorithm is used to derive an inverse of the forward scattering operator, which is defined as the projection of the object function onto the measurement space.
* *The HSIW method is applied to the collected data to estimate the object function, which is expanded in terms of the singular vectors vj(r) and the coefficients αj are determined by solving the normal equations.* The resulting object function is used to reconstruct the image of the medium surrounding the physical probe.

• The invention relates to a biological oil composition derived from a marine copepod, particularly from the species Calanus finmarchicus, which has a unique fatty acid composition and is rich in stearidonic acid (SDA).
• The oil composition has been found to have anti-atherogenic properties, inhibiting the formation of atherosclerotic plaques and reducing total blood cholesterol levels.
• The composition is characterized by a high content of wax esters, with a typical composition of 70-100% by weight, and also contains SDA, eicosapentaenoic acid (EPA), and docosahexaenoic acid (DHA).
• The oil composition has been tested in mice deficient in apolipoprotein E (ApoE) and has been found to be effective in preventing the development of atherosclerotic plaques and reducing blood cholesterol levels.
• The invention also provides various formulations and methods for using the biological oil composition as a dietary supplement, functional food, or pharmaceutical product for the prevention and treatment of cardiovascular disease.

* *The invention relates to pharmacological compositions containing polyelectrolyte complexes in microparticulate form and at least one active substance. The active substance can be embedded in the matrix of the polyelectrolyte complex, be a partner in the polyelectrolyte complex, or be bound to a partner of the polyelectrolyte complex. The polyelectrolyte complexes can be composed of biocompatible, biodegradable polyacids and polybases.*
* *The polyelectrolyte complexes can be prepared by mixing a solution of an acidic and a solution of a basic substance, where at least one of these substances must be polymeric. The resulting complex can be precipitated in microparticulate form or converted into a microparticulate form.*
* *The incorporation of an active substance in the polyelectrolyte complex particles can be carried out in at least four ways: entrapment of the active substance, absorption of the active substance, precipitation of the polyelectrolyte complex, or employing the active substance as a partner in the formation of the polyelectrolyte complex.*
* *The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be used as a vaccine delivery system, allowing for controlled release of the vaccine and improved immunogenicity. The particles can be administered subcutaneously or intramuscularly.*
* *The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can also be used as a depot system for peptide-based active substances, allowing for controlled release and improved bioavailability. The particles can be used to deliver LHRH analogs and other peptide-based active substances.*
* *The polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be used as an echogenic injectable contrast agent for ultrasonic diagnosis, allowing for the visualization of small blood vessels and other structures.*
* *The release of active substances from the polyelectrolyte complex microparticles can be controlled by adjusting the composition of the complex, the particle size, and the release conditions. The release profiles can be tailored to specific applications, such as vaccine delivery or depot systems.*

* The invention is a dental apparatus that provides a simple and effective means for cleaning teeth and massaging gums. It consists of a mouthpiece with upper and lower channel members that fit over the teeth and gums, and a control box that provides air pulses and water or cleaning fluid to the mouthpiece.
* The mouthpiece has a membrane structure that provides a sealed area for the air pulses and fluid to flow through, and bite blocks that hold the teeth in place during use. The air pulses are provided by an air pump in the control box, which alternately inflates and deflates air-sacks along the hose to create a massaging action on the gums.
* The fluid flow through the mouthpiece is controlled by the control box, which can provide a gentle steady stream of water or cleaning fluid to clean and flush out the teeth and gums. The fluid also serves as a lubricant during the massaging action.
* The apparatus has a suction hose that draws out any fluid that seeps out of the mouth during use, and a drain pan in the control box that collects the drained fluid. The control box also has three ON-OFF switches to provide different modes of operation, including air only, water only, and both air and water.
* The apparatus can be operated from the control box or a remote control device, which is a handheld device with switches that correspond to the ON-OFF switches on the control box.

* The invention relates to pelvic floor reconstruction using implants, particularly for treating pelvic organ prolapse (POP). The invention provides a reliable anchoring of the mesh implant and a method for threading the straps of the implant through the ligaments. The invention also provides a needle with a trap mechanism for trapping the strap end and a mechanism for releasing the trap.
* The anterior implant includes four straps, each ending with a looped end, and a loop between two interior straps for anchoring to the cervix. The posterior implant includes two straps, each ending with a looped end, and a loop at the opposing side for anchoring to the perineal body. Both implants may include spaces for reducing the weight of the implant.
* The needle has a rod that can be manually slid back and forth in a track within the body of the needle. The edge of the rod can be inserted into a niche, and the tip of the needle is located at the edge of the body. The needle can be flexible and thin, allowing it to occupy minimal surgery space.
* The method for threading the straps of the implant includes inserting the looped end of the strap into the niche, trapping it by the rod edge, and then pushing the tip of the needle through the ligament. The surgeon then releases the looped end from the needle by toggling the toggle arm, and pulls the needle back, leaving the strap at the side beyond.
* The invention provides a reliable and secure anchoring of the implant to the ligaments, eliminating the need for additional perforations of the body from the opposing direction. The invention also provides a simple and efficient method for threading the straps of the implant through the ligaments.
* The invention can be used for reconstructing the anterior and posterior pelvic floor, including prolapse of the urinary bladder, colon, small intestine, and uterus. The invention provides a reliable and secure anchoring of the implant to the ligaments, eliminating the need for additional perforations of the body from the opposing direction.

• The invention relates to methods and apparatus for providing ventilatory assistance to a subject, particularly for subjects with severe lung disease, chest wall disease, neuromuscular disease, or respiratory control disorders. The invention aims to provide a ventilator that can accurately match the phase and degree of assistance to the subject's spontaneous efforts, automatically adjust the degree of assistance to maintain a specified minimum ventilation, and provide immunity to the effects of sudden leaks. The invention uses fuzzy logic to determine the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle and to calculate the desired instantaneous delivery pressure.

• The apparatus includes a blower, a mask, a pneumotachograph, a differential pressure transducer, and a microprocessor. The microprocessor samples the mask flow signal and the pressure signal and sends an instantaneous mask pressure request signal to a servo, which compares the pressure request signal with the actual pressure signal to control the fan motor.

• The microprocessor is programmed to perform a series of fuzzy inference rules to determine the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle. The rules are based on the magnitude and rate of change of the respiratory airflow.

• The fuzzy inference rules are used to determine the phase in the respiratory cycle, including start inspiration, early inspiration, peak inspiration, late inspiration, start expiration, early expiration, peak expiration, late expiration, and expiratory pause.

• The microprocessor also calculates the desired instantaneous delivery pressure as a function of the instantaneous phase in the respiratory cycle using a pressure waveform function Π(Φ).

• The pressure waveform function Π(Φ) is chosen such that the desired delivery pressure at phase Φ will be given by P=P0+AΠ(Φ), where P0 is the desired end expiratory pressure and A is the desired increase in pressure above P0 at end inspiration.

• The microprocessor initializes the phase Φ in the respiratory cycle to zero and initializes the current estimates of actual inspiratory and expiratory duration TI and TE to TT TGT respectively.

• The microprocessor also initializes the rate of change of phase during inspiration ΔΦI and expiration ΔΦE to 0.5T/TITGT and 0.5T/TE TGT respectively.

• The microprocessor measures the instantaneous respiratory airflow fRESP and calculates the average total breath duration TT=TI+TE.

• The microprocessor low pass filters the respiratory airflow with an adjustable time constant τf, where τf is a fixed small fraction of TT.

• The invention relates to a novel electro-surgical instrument for use in laparoscopic/endoscopic procedures, which aims to improve the surgeon's view of the operation site and prevent unintentional cauterization of healthy tissue.
• The instrument includes a rigid insulating sleeve, a conductive rod, and a working tip electrode, with a rigid arm extending from the sleeve to the working tip electrode, which is laterally offset from the longitudinal axis of the sleeve.
• The arm is designed to space the working tip electrode from the sleeve, allowing for maximum visualization of the surgical work site and preventing obstruction of the surgeon's view.
• The working tip electrode comes in various shapes, such as a hook and a flattened spatula, and is used to perform different surgical tasks, including grasping and pulling at tissue, and cauterizing bleeding blood vessels.
• The instrument is designed to be used in laparoscopic procedures, where the surgeon inserts the instrument into the abdomen through a trochar and views the operation site through a laparoscope.
• The instrument is designed to be easy to handle and use, with a single-use, disposable design that eliminates the need for sterilization and reduces the risk of cross-contamination.

<summary>
• The invention relates to a magnetic resonance imaging (MRI) apparatus that allows for high-contrast exposures in a short time, even for larger body segments.
• In known MRI apparatuses, exposure parameters must be modified for different exposure positions, which requires a readjustment of the apparatus.
• The invention determines the required adjustment parameters in a preceding adjustment process, rather than immediately before each individual exposure.
• The adjustment parameters are stored in a memory until the conclusion of the examination, allowing for reduced examination times.
• The apparatus has a support plate that can be displaced longitudinally, allowing for examination of larger body sections.
• The transmit and receive coils can be connected or disconnected, and their configuration can be modified, to optimize the RF chain and homogeneity of the main magnetic field.
• The adjustment parameters include the position of the support plate, the configuration of the transmit and receive coils, and corresponding control signals for the generator, amplifiers, and receiver.
• The invention allows for high-contrast exposures without omitting adjustments, making it suitable for examinations such as tracking doses of contrast agent over a larger body region.

* The invention relates to a fastener for albums, such as photographic albums and scrapbooks, that allows for easy addition and removal of pages.
* The fastener consists of a strap that passes through the album from the front to the back and a pair of strap anchors attached to the front and back covers.
* Each strap anchor is a channel with a base and a pair of locking lips that engage with the strap to prevent it from being pulled out.
* The strap has parallel ribs that engage with the ribs on the base of the channel to prevent it from being pulled out.
* The strap anchors are attached to the front and back covers of the album using adhesive, such as adhesive tape.
* The strap is designed to be flexible enough to be easily inserted into the channel and rigid enough to be easily removed from the channel.
* The fastener allows for adjustment of the album's size by incorporating additional pages, and the strap can be released from either end of the album.
* The fastener is designed to be inexpensive to produce and can be used in albums that are cost-sensitive.

• The present invention relates to a sulky comprising two wheels, individually fastened to a common frame, with the objective of providing a lightweight and durable construction that can be easily assembled and transported. The sulky is designed to be manufactured using light metal and other lightweight materials, with a focus on reducing weight while maintaining strength. The sulky is intended for use in trotting races and requires a lightweight construction that is easy to run and strong enough to withstand the strain of exercise and competition.

• The sulky has a unique design that allows it to be assembled easily by the user, with all components being flat and requiring only a small space for storage and transportation. The sulky is designed to be disassembled and reassembled quickly, making it easy to transport and store. The user can assemble the sulky in a quarter of an hour, making it a convenient and practical option.

• The sulky has a stable construction, with the shafts and crossbar transferring all the load to the wheel planes. The sulky is designed to be strong and durable, with a focus on providing a stable and reliable ride. The sulky is intended to be used in trotting races, where speed and agility are important, and the sulky's design is intended to provide a smooth and stable ride.
