• The present invention provides a new, useful, and non-obvious method of singulating and plating semiconductor packages, employing plating of the side surfaces of the leads of the leadframe in order to prevent contamination of the lead surfaces.
• The singulation and plating process can be performed using full cutting, where the leadframe is cut in one full cutting operation, or partial cutting, where the leadframe is cut in multiple partial cutting operations.
• The plating material used in the present invention is preferably a material configured not to react with oxygen, and can be a metallic material such as tin, silver, gold, nickel-gold, nickel-palladium, or nickel-palladium-gold.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a dual mode mobile terminal that can selectively connect to a wireless wide area network (WWAN) and a wireless local area network (WLAN).
* The mobile terminal has a first network module for connecting to the WWAN and a second network module for connecting to the WLAN.
* When the mobile terminal connects to the WLAN, the second network module receives service information from a second base station, which contains signal strength, channel information, and base station identity codes of the WWAN's first base stations.
* The mobile terminal can turn on the first network module and select a serving base station from the WWAN's first base stations according to the service information when the signal level of the WLAN's transmitting signal becomes low.
* The mobile terminal can skip some initial scanning procedures of the first network module by using the service information, which can accelerate the connecting procedures.
* The invention can be used in various situations, including when the mobile terminal is in a calling status, idle status, or any other status, and can switch the connecting from WLAN to WWAN accordingly.

* The invention relates to a new process for producing multilayered components, such as capacitors, coils, and resistors, using a decal-based method. The process involves depositing electrodes and electrical components onto a decal, and then stacking the decals to form a multilayered structure. This method eliminates the need for cutting and laminating, which can cause defects and reduce yields.
* The process begins with the preparation of decals, which are flexible sheets of material that are coated with a transfer release agent. The decals are then used as a carrier for the electrodes and electrical components.
* Electrodes are deposited onto the decals using a screen printing process, and electrical components are deposited onto the electrodes using a similar process. The electrodes and components are then cured to form a solid bond.
* The decals are then stacked to form a multilayered structure, with the electrodes and components aligned to form a desired configuration. The decals are then removed, leaving a multilayered component.
* The process can be used to produce a wide range of components, including capacitors, coils, and resistors. The components can be designed to have specific electrical properties, such as capacitance, inductance, and resistance.
* The process is more efficient and cost-effective than traditional methods, which require cutting and laminating. The decal-based method also allows for greater precision and control over the component's electrical properties.
* The invention also includes a method for producing a multilayer ferrite inductor, which involves depositing a spiral coil pattern onto a decal and then stacking the decals to form a multilayered structure.
* The decal-based method can also be used to produce other types of components, such as transformer configurations, magnetic amplifiers, and saturable reactors.
* The invention has many advantages, including the ability to produce small parts, lower voltage ratings, and no shape limitations. The process also eliminates cutting stress cracks and internal delamination.
* The decal-based method is a versatile and cost-effective way to produce a wide range of electronic components, and it has many potential applications in the field of electronics.

<summary>
• The process described is a co-production of power and hydrocarbons, which includes a coal-to-liquid (CTL) facility and an Integrated Gasification Combined Cycle (IGCC) facility. The CTL facility produces synthesis gas precursor, which is then enriched in hydrogen and converted to hydrocarbons in a Fischer-Tropsch process. The IGCC facility produces combustion gas, which is used to generate power in a gas turbine expander.
• The CTL facility includes a dry gasification stage, a gas clean-up stage, a Fischer-Tropsch hydrocarbon synthesis stage, and a product work-up stage. The dry gasification stage produces synthesis gas precursor, which is then cleaned and converted to hydrocarbons in the Fischer-Tropsch process. The product work-up stage produces LPG, naphta, and diesel from the hydrocarbons.
• The IGCC facility includes a wet gasification stage, a sour shift stage, a hydrogen-enriched gas expansion stage, and a gas combustion and expansion stage. The wet gasification stage produces combustion gas, which is then cleaned and used to generate power in the gas turbine expander. The sour shift stage converts CO and water to CO2 and H2, which is then used to produce hydrogen-enriched gas.
• The process also includes an air separation unit, a CO2 and water separation stage, and a water treatment stage. The air separation unit produces oxygen and nitrogen, which are used in the CTL and IGCC facilities. The CO2 and water separation stage removes CO2 and water from the Fischer-Tropsch tail gas, and the water treatment stage treats the water produced in the process.

<summary>
* *The present invention provides a method for preparing a solid device for use as an oxide superconducting material, which is kept superconductive at the surface or portion close to the surface of the oxide superconducting material. This is accomplished by providing a blocking film (passivation film) which is uniformly coated over the spaces or micro-holes in the surface portion of the superconducting material to prevent the removal of oxygen from that portion.*
* *The blocking film is formed on the surface of the superconducting material using a photo-CVD method, and oxygen is added to the surface or portion close to the surface of the superconducting material by ion injection or hot oxidation. The film is then converted to a highly dense insulating material by heat treatment, and the oxygen concentration in the region at the surface or close to it is controlled by solid phase to solid phase diffusion of the oxygen.*</summary>

<summary>
• The present invention relates to an apparatus for preparing foam sheet samples for microscopic examination, which is particularly useful for examining the cell structure of foam materials used in various applications such as containers, meat trays, and packaging materials.
• The apparatus includes a base plate, support columns, a clamp bar, and a threaded member with a hand nut that allows for precise control over the advancement of the foam sample and the cutting of parallel slices.
• The apparatus enables the preparation of foam samples with parallel cut edges, which preserves the structure of the individual cells and allows for even transmission of light during microscopic examination, providing valuable insights into the properties and performance of the foam materials.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a method and apparatus for determining the angle of inclination with respect to the vertical assumed by a seismometer, especially one designed to operate on the ocean floor.
* The seismometer has a frame, floats, an instrument compartment, and a ballast tube, which provides good seismic coupling between the frame and the ocean bottom.
* The invention includes a geophone suspended at the end of a shaft protruding from a ball rotating in an annular seat, forming a free-moving pendulum.
* The geophone is connected to a plunger, which is restrained from contacting the ball by a pin connected to a linearly acting solenoid.
* The solenoid is activated to remove the pin, allowing the plunger to extend and lock the geophone in its assumed position.
* The angle of inclination is determined by measuring the acute angle formed by the line passing through the center of gravity of the geophone and the center of the ball when the geophone is in its clamped position.
* The invention also provides a simple and inexpensive apparatus for self-leveling seismic motion detectors used in the seismometer.
* The invention is useful for determining the angle of inclination of a seismometer on the ocean floor, which is important for evaluating the data gathered and the causes of any failure to obtain data or suitable data.
* The invention is a novel device for leveling seismic motion detectors and preserving the orientation assumed by the seismometer, allowing for accurate measurement of the angle of inclination.

<summary>
• The present invention provides a humidity sensing element that is energized by low voltage microscopic currents from solid state electronic instrumentation, does not depend on mechanical movements, and is physically sturdy and requires no special physical protection. The element consists of a first electron conductive electrode, a porous coating of dielectric, minute particles of electron conductive material deposited in the interstices of the porosity of the dielectric, and a second electron conductive electrode pervious to moisture vapor. The impedance between the electrodes varies generally linearly with relation to the relative humidity of the surrounding gaseous atmosphere in a suitable range of interest when excited by a suitable alternating current voltage.
• The preferred embodiment of the invention includes a tubular aluminum first electrode member whose bore has been anodized, the anodized layer impregnated with nickel particles by vacuum deposition, and the anodized layer sealed. The sealed anodized layer is then overlaid with a porous vacuum deposition of nickel to form a second electrode. The sensor is suitable for excitation by a ten Hertz sine wave alternating current electrical voltage impressed across its electrodes by a solid state electronic measurement circuit.
• The sensor is designed to have an impedance that decreases generally linearly proportionally to the relative humidity of the atmosphere to which it is exposed, and the impedance changes almost instantly in response to relative humidity changes due to the thin and molecularly porous dielectric and second electrode. The sensor is suitable for use in textile mills, which typically require temperatures between 75° F. and 85° F. and relative humidities between 40% and 85%. The sensor is designed to be self-contained and forms its own protection for the humidity-sensitive portion in its bore.

<summary>
* The invention relates to a motor assembly with a force transmission structure, which includes a drive plate and a shaft. The drive plate has a mounting hole with at least three sections interconnected at a common area, and the shaft has a toothed portion with at least three teeth fittingly received in the sections of the mounting hole. The drive plate is driven by a worm gear through a damper, and the shaft is connected to a pinion that drives a gear of a window lift system. The force transmission structure is designed to reduce vibration and noise.
* The motor assembly includes a motor, a gear train, and a force transmission structure. The gear train includes a worm, a worm gear, and a damper, and the force transmission structure includes a drive plate and a shaft. The drive plate has a Y-shaped mounting hole and a coupling with buffer holes, and the shaft has a Y-shaped toothed portion that fits into the mounting hole. The drive plate is made of an engineering plastics material and has V-shaped protrusions that fit into slots in the damper.
* The shaft is made of low alloy steel and has a pinion that drives a gear of the window lift system. The motor assembly is designed to rotate the shaft quietly and stably, and the drive plate is designed to absorb vibration and reduce noise. The buffer holes in the coupling of the drive plate provide relief when the plastics material is cooling in the mold, reducing distortion of the mounting hole.
* The motor assembly is designed to be compact and efficient, and the force transmission structure is designed to reduce vibration and noise. The drive plate is designed to be made of an engineering plastics material that has good strength and resistance to impact, and the shaft is designed to be made of low alloy steel that can withstand a high torque. The motor assembly is suitable for use in a window lift system, and the force transmission structure is designed to provide a smooth and quiet operation.

<summary>

• The present invention provides a method and system for generating a mobile time reference for a portable transceiver. The system includes an antenna, a radio frequency subsystem, and a baseband subsystem. The radio frequency subsystem includes a high frequency oscillator and a low frequency oscillator, and the baseband subsystem includes a free running counter that generates the mobile time reference. The mobile time reference is used to detect, identify, and monitor multipath signals in a WCDMA system.

• The free running counter uses the high frequency oscillator to generate the mobile time reference when the portable transceiver is in active mode, and uses the low frequency oscillator to maintain the mobile time reference when the portable transceiver is in idle mode. The low frequency oscillator is phase locked to the high frequency oscillator, and an estimate of the drift and bias of the low frequency oscillator is made using a Kalman estimation. The mobile time reference is updated using the cycles of the low frequency clock counted when the high frequency clock is not available and the estimated drift/bias of the low frequency clock. This allows the mobile time reference to be maintained during idle mode, which reduces power consumption and extends battery life.

• The mobile time reference is used to detect, identify, and monitor multipath signals in a WCDMA system. The system includes a multipath monitor and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit, which use the mobile time reference to recover the multipath signals and operate a multipath signal receiver. The multipath monitor includes a primary sync searcher, a secondary sync searcher, and a gold code searcher, which provide information regarding the searches to the microprocessor. The multipath radio signal recovery circuit includes a deskewing and timing controller, which time aligns the outputs of the multipath signals relative to one another.

• The system also includes a WCDMA modem, which uses the mobile time reference to recover the multipath signals and operate a multipath signal receiver. The WCDMA modem includes a receiver equalizer, a multipath monitor, and a multipath radio signal recovery circuit, which use the mobile time reference to recover the multipath signals and operate a multipath signal receiver. The receiver equalizer equalizes the digital signal from the receiver BAP, and the multipath monitor and multipath radio signal recovery circuit use the mobile time reference to recover the multipath signals and operate a multipath signal receiver.

<summary>
* The background of the invention discusses the need for a protective helmet with a custom-fitted liner that can absorb shock and accommodate different head sizes.
* The existing methods of making custom-fitted helmets have limitations, such as the need for direct handling of foaming agents or the complexity of preformed liners.
* The invention provides a helmet liner with a plurality of layers, each consisting of an elastic thermoplastic sheet formed with an array of pockets.
* The pockets are open and unfilled, allowing them to deform in response to compressive contact with an adjacent layer.
* The liner is fitted to an individual's head by heating the sheets to a plastic state, placing the liner between an outer fixture and the head, and removing the liner when it has cooled to a rigid, nonplastic state.
* The liner can be refitted to accommodate a changed head size by reheating the sheets and re-deforming them to the new size.
* The liner resists the tendency to shift position on the wearer's head due to its compliance and ability to conform to the contours of the head.
* The liner does not require the use of drawstrings or the like during fitting or require trimming afterward.
* The invention provides a simple and inexpensive method for making a custom-fitted helmet liner that can be rapidly and easily fitted to an individual's head.

• The invention relates to a multiorifice structure and a method of fabrication, specifically a multiorifice structure spray disc for use in an automotive fuel injector valve. The structure has a plurality of angularly disposed passages and is made by fusing concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members. Each layer of rods is disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into relatively thin wafers, forming a plurality of multiorifice structures.

• The multiorifice structure has a unique configuration, with triangularly shaped orifices that are more effective in atomizing the exiting fluid than circular orifices of the prior art. The triangular orifices are formed by the interstices between the individual rods and cylindrical members. The thickness of the structure is a function of the effective aperture of the interstices and is selected to impart a directional component to the fluid passing through the interstices. The structure is designed to produce a uniform spray pattern with a high degree of atomization.

• The method of fabrication involves fusing concentric layers of solid rods and cylindrical members, with each layer of rods disposed at a progressively larger angle with respect to the axis of the fused assembly. The fused assembly is then cut into relatively thin wafers, forming a plurality of multiorifice structures. The rods and cylindrical members may be coated with a thin layer of material having a lower melting temperature to facilitate fusion. The structure may be made from a variety of materials, including metals, glass, and plastics.

• The multiorifice structure has several advantages over prior art structures, including improved atomization and a more uniform spray pattern. The triangular orifices are more effective in breaking up the exiting fluid into small droplets, resulting in a more efficient combustion process. The structure is also more durable and resistant to clogging than prior art structures. The method of fabrication is simple and economical, making it well-suited for high-volume production.

• The invention has several applications, including use in automotive fuel injector valves, industrial spray nozzles, and medical devices. The multiorifice structure can be used to dispense a variety of fluids, including fuels, chemicals, and pharmaceuticals. The structure can be designed to produce a specific spray pattern or droplet size, making it suitable for a wide range of applications. The invention has the potential to revolutionize the field of fluid dispensing and atomization.

• The invention is not limited to the specific configuration and method

* The invention relates to a method of manufacturing a semiconductor device, particularly an insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor device having a lightly doped drain (LDD) structure.
* The method includes forming a gate insulating film and a gate electrode on a substrate, and then forming a low concentration n-type region by injecting impurities through the gate insulating film.
* The method also includes forming a high concentration n-type region by injecting impurities through the gate insulating film and the gate electrode, and then removing the gate insulating film and the gate electrode to form a LDD structure.
* The method can be used to fabricate both n-channel and p-channel insulated gate (MOS) field effect semiconductor devices, and can be applied to various semiconductor devices such as MOSFETs and ICs.

* The present invention relates to an improved end-user interface for Internet-protocol (IP) telephone communication, which provides a low-cost and efficient IP telephone solution. The invention enhances a radio telephone to work in conjunction with a PC-based telephony application, allowing computationally intensive speech coding and decoding to be performed external to the PC. This results in a more convenient, economical, and efficient IP telephone system.
* The invention includes an enhanced radio telephone with a speech coder, a speech decompressor, an antenna, a radio frequency transceiver, a digital interface, and an external connection. The speech coder compresses and codes speech signals, while the speech decompressor decompresses and decodes speech signals. The radio frequency transceiver transmits and receives radio signals, and the digital interface connects the enhanced radio telephone to the PC.
* The invention allows the enhanced radio telephone to operate in two modes: a wireless-telephone mode and an IP-telephone mode. In the wireless-telephone mode, the enhanced radio telephone operates as a conventional wireless telephone, transmitting and receiving radio signals. In the IP-telephone mode, the enhanced radio telephone communicates with a PC-based telephony application, which converts between coded speech data and network-formatted data.
* The invention provides several advantages over conventional IP telephones, including reduced delay and signal quality, a more convenient and comfortable handset, and reduced echo problems. The enhanced radio telephone can also provide echo canceling circuitry, and the PC-based telephony application can be streamlined to reduce the need for a high-performance PC.
* The invention can be implemented using a standard serial or parallel PC cable connection, or alternative connections such as infrared or shortwave radio. The enhanced radio telephone and PC-based telephony application can be programmed to allow IP-telephone operation to be controlled from either the PC or the enhanced radio telephone.
* The invention is not limited to the specific exemplary embodiments described, and can be modified and adapted to suit different applications and requirements. The scope of the invention is defined by the appended claims, and all equivalents which are consistent with the meaning of the claims are intended to be embraced therein.

* The present invention is a wave energy converter that uses a submerged, partially evacuated or surface-vented, reinforced flexible bellows container to capture energy from ocean waves.
* The container has a fixed depth and is connected to a hydraulic or pneumatic drive system that converts the energy of the waves into mechanical or electrical energy.
* The container is designed to capture both the heave and surge components of wave energy, and its shape and orientation can be adjusted to optimize energy capture.
* The invention also includes features such as a tidal depth adjusting system, a hydraulic circuit with control valves, and a power pod that houses the hydraulic motor, electric generator, and controls.
* The invention is designed to be more efficient and cost-effective than previous wave energy converters, and it can be used to generate electricity or other forms of energy from ocean waves.

The cigarette magazine has a storage part and four shaft groups arranged beneath it, and the cigarettes are monitored by a camera and an image-processing device. The camera scans an image of the cigarette magazine, and the image-processing device evaluates the image to detect any defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes. If a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, an error signal is produced, which results in the actuation of an ejecting unit to eject the defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette.
* *The ejecting unit has a housing, a carriage, and an ejector, and is arranged in the region of the magazine. The ejecting unit is displaced in the direction of the chute when a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, and the ejected cigarette drops into the chute.
* *The cigarette magazine has a transparent front wall in the region of the evaluation zones, allowing the camera to view the cigarette ends. The camera is arranged on the front and rear sides of the cigarette magazine, and the image-processing device evaluates the images from both cameras to detect any defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes. The image-processing device produces an error signal if a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, which results in the actuation of the ejecting unit.
* *The ejecting unit is actuated when a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected, and it ejects the defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette into the chute. The ejecting unit is also actuated manually, for example to take samples or to eliminate errors that are not detected automatically. * *The cigarette magazine has four evaluation zones, each corresponding to a region of the magazine that is monitored by the camera. The image-processing device evaluates the images from the camera to detect any defective or incorrectly positioned cigarettes in each evaluation zone. If a defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette is detected in an evaluation zone, the corresponding ejecting unit is actuated to eject the defective or incorrectly positioned cigarette.

<summary>
* The invention is a device for connecting high voltage cables to apparatus and/or other high voltage cables, comprising a cable termination and a rigid insulator. The device provides a simplified connection system for high voltage cables with ratings up to 400 KV and above.
* The device has a common cable connection system for all accessories and interconnections, resulting in advantages such as factory pretesting, reduced installation time and cost, reduced tools, and simplified field testing. The interface components do not include any gas or oil and therefore cannot leak or explode.
* The device has a stress cone design and dimensions that are the same for all applications, with the only variation being the diameter of the cable or apparatus entrance. The device also has a further advantage in that it does not require any gas or oil and therefore cannot leak or explode.
* The device has been illustrated in various embodiments, including an SF6 terminal, a transformer terminal, an out-door terminal, a straight through joint, a transition joint, and a joint between two apparatus. The device has been shown to have a compact design, lower material and installation cost, and complete independence between gas insulated switch gear and cable installations.

* The invention relates to a fixing mechanism for a tool, which can be used in various applications such as machining, cutting, punching, molding, and forming work. The mechanism comprises a tool, a tool frame, and a tool holder, and is characterized by a curved surface that allows for a simple and secure fixing of the tool. The curved surface is formed by a second connecting surface in the tool holder and a first connecting surface in the tool frame.
* The fixing mechanism can be used in various embodiments, including a first embodiment where the tool frame has a cylindrical shape and the tool holder has a spherical shape, and a second embodiment where the tool frame has a spherical shape and the tool holder has a cylindrical shape. The mechanism can also be used in a third embodiment where the tool frame has a ball mechanism that allows for the tool to be fixed and released.

* The present invention provides methods and apparatus for producing low EMI energy at levels necessary to drive varying sizes of digital displays, including large displays such as the touch screen on the Apple iPhone, without generating the negative effects of high EMI radiation.
* The invention achieves this by configuring the parallel source and drain paths in a specific manner, interleaving them to cancel out EMI produced on one path by the EMI produced on one or more adjacent paths, and optionally using terminal paths to further reduce EMI effects.

<summary>
* *The text describes a method for rebalancing and charging a battery pack in a vehicle, which involves determining the maximum capacity of each cell, determining the common voltage needed for each cell to support a target drive range, and determining the charge time for the battery pack. The method also involves determining the resistive circuitry activation time for each cell and balancing and charging the cells accordingly. The goal is to minimize the time spent rebalancing and charging the battery pack.
* *The method involves using algorithms to determine the required cell voltage, the charge time, and the resistive circuitry activation time for each cell. The algorithms take into account the maximum capacity of each cell, the target drive range, and the charge current rate. The method also involves activating the resistive circuitry for each cell and deactivating it when the activation time has expired, and disabling the battery charger when the charge time has expired.

• The invention is a system for controlling the illumination levels in a space, including both daylight and artificial lighting, and for reducing sun glare. The system includes a central processor, a dimming panel, photosensors, and a window treatment controller. The central processor is a Lutron GRAFIK 6000 central lighting processor.

• The dimming panel has various lighting loads, such as incandescent, fluorescent, and LED lights, which can be controlled by the central processor. The dimming panel is a Lutron type GP12-1203ML-15. The photosensors are microWATT photosensors available from Lutron model No. MW-PS-WH.

• The photosensors are for control of the interior lights and are mounted at approximately two window heights away from the windows. The photosensors measure the light reflected off the surfaces in the illuminated space. The photosensors are preferably mounted with no or minimal daylight shining directly into the photosensor.

• The window treatment controller is a Lutron GRAFIK 6000 Sivoia controller model No. SO-SVCI-WH-EO1. The window treatment controller allows manual control of the window treatments. The window treatments are Lutron Sivoia roller shades, Kit no. SV-RS-KIT.

• The system also includes a computer, for example a personal computer, which is coupled to the central processor via an interface adapter. The computer is used for programming and monitoring of the central processor. The computer is connected to the central processor via a PC jack.

• The system can be programmed to create and recall custom preset scenes. The preset scenes can be created using the computer and the central processor. The preset scenes can be recalled using the wall stations or the computer.

• The system can also be controlled manually using wall stations. The wall stations are coupled to the central processor and the photosensor interfaces. The wall stations allow manual control of the lighting loads and the window treatments.

• The system can be used in a variety of applications, including residential and commercial spaces. The system can be used to control lighting levels, reduce sun glare, and create a comfortable and energy-efficient environment.

• The system is designed to be flexible and can be customized to meet the specific needs of the user. The system can be programmed to control multiple lighting loads and window treatments, and can be controlled using a variety of methods, including manual control and automated control.

This approach is critical to ensuring that the TSA is focusing on the most critical areas of aviation security.*

* *The TSA has also made significant investments in technology, including the development of the Computer-Assisted Passenger Prescreening System (CAPPS II), which will help to improve the efficiency and effectiveness of passenger screening. The TSA is also exploring the use of biometric technology to improve passenger screening.*

* *The TSA has also taken steps to improve the security of air cargo, including the implementation of a known shipper program and the use of explosives detection systems to screen cargo. The TSA is also working to improve the security of general aviation, which is a vulnerable area of the aviation system.*

* *The TSA has also made significant investments in infrastructure, including the construction of new security checkpoints and the installation of explosives detection systems. The TSA is also working to improve the security of airport perimeters, which is a critical area of vulnerability.*

* *The TSA has also taken steps to improve the security of the air traffic control system, including the implementation of a new air traffic control system and the use of encryption to protect sensitive information. The TSA is also working to improve the security of the air traffic control facilities, which are critical to the safe and efficient operation of the air traffic control system.*

* *The TSA has also made significant investments in training and workforce development, including the training of federal air marshals and the development of a new training program for passenger screeners. The TSA is also working to improve the security of the air traffic control workforce, which is critical to the safe and efficient operation of the air traffic control system.*

The TSA is also working to improve the security of the air traffic control system, which is critical to the safe and efficient operation of the air traffic control system.*

<summary>

* The Lobbying Disclosure Act (LDA) and the Internal Revenue Code (IRC) have different definitions of lobbying, which can affect who must register and what information must be reported. The LDA definition covers contacts with federal officials, while the IRC definitions cover contacts with federal, state, and local officials. The differences in definitions can result in organizations not registering under LDA or reporting information that is not comparable.
* The LDA definition covers more federal officials than the IRC definitions, particularly for nonlegislative matters. This means that organizations using the LDA definition may have to report more information and may be required to register under LDA. In contrast, organizations using the IRC definitions may not have to report as much information or register under LDA.
* The IRC definitions have exceptions that can exclude certain lobbying expenses from being reported. For example, the IRC section 4911 definition has an exception for nonpartisan analysis, which can exclude significant lobbying expenses. This can result in organizations reporting less information and avoiding registration under LDA.
* The choice of definition can affect the information reported on lobbying reports. Organizations using the LDA definition must report all expenses for lobbying covered federal government officials, while organizations using the IRC definitions may only report expenses for federal lobbying. This can result in different information being reported and less comparability between organizations.
* The LDA requires organizations to report information on issues addressed during lobbying contacts and the House of Congress and federal agencies contacted. However, organizations using the IRC definitions may not have to report this information for nonfederal lobbying. This can result in less information being reported and less comparability between organizations.
* The differences in definitions can affect the number of organizations that register under LDA. Organizations using the IRC definitions may not have to register under LDA, while organizations using the LDA definition may have to register. This can result in less information being reported and less transparency in lobbying activities.
* The LDA requires organizations to report their total estimated expenses for all activities covered by the definition. However, organizations using the IRC definitions may not have to report all expenses, which can result in less information being reported and less comparability between organizations.

• The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has been assessing strategic sourcing and its potential value in federal acquisitions for over a decade, and has found that leading companies have been able to save 4-15% of their spending by strategically sourcing services. The GAO has recommended that the federal government adopt similar practices to achieve cost savings.
• The GAO has identified several challenges to implementing strategic sourcing in the federal government, including a lack of reliable and detailed data on spending, a lack of trained acquisition personnel, and a lack of leadership commitment. The GAO has also found that agencies have been reluctant to apply strategic sourcing to services, which account for over half of federal procurement spending.
• The GAO has reported that companies use a variety of tactics to strategically source services, including leveraging scale, standardizing requirements, prequalifying suppliers, and understanding cost drivers. Companies also aim to commoditize services over the long term by reducing complexity and increasing competition.
• The GAO has recommended that the federal government take a series of steps to improve strategic sourcing efforts, including evaluating the need for additional guidance, resources, and strategies, and focusing on high-spending categories such as services. The GAO has also called for agencies to adopt leading practices and to increase the amount of spending through strategic sourcing.

<summary>

* *The current surface transportation program is not effectively addressing the nation's transportation challenges, and a reexamination of the federal role in transportation is needed to ensure a sustainable and effective program. The program is not well-defined, and the federal government's role is unclear, leading to a lack of focus and accountability. The program's goals and priorities are not well-aligned, and the funding mechanism is not sustainable.
* *The Highway Trust Fund is facing a shortfall, and the current funding mechanism is not sustainable. The fund's revenues have not kept pace with inflation, and the fund's expenses have increased. The fund's sustainability is threatened by the increasing demand for transportation infrastructure and the decreasing revenue from fuel taxes.
* *The federal government has several options for financing infrastructure projects, including bonding, loan guarantees, and credit assistance. Bonding can provide upfront capital for infrastructure projects, but it can be more expensive for the federal government than traditional federal grants. Loan guarantees and credit assistance can provide financing for infrastructure projects, but they also involve risk for the federal government.
* *Public-private partnerships (PPPs) can be used to finance infrastructure projects, but they also involve risks and challenges. PPPs can provide upfront capital for infrastructure projects, but they can also lead to higher costs and reduced public control. The federal government needs to carefully consider the public interest and weigh the benefits and costs of PPPs.
* *The federal government needs to reexamine its role in transportation and develop a more sustainable and effective program. The program should be based on a clear set of goals and priorities, and the funding mechanism should be sustainable and equitable. The program should also involve public-private partnerships and other innovative financing mechanisms to address the nation's transportation challenges.

• The current funding system for the Federal Aviation Administration (FAA) is based on excise taxes, which do not accurately reflect the costs imposed by different flights on the National Airspace System (NAS). The current system has raised concerns about revenue adequacy, equity, and efficiency, as some flights pay more or less than the costs they impose on the system.
• Alternative funding options, such as a fuel tax, passenger segment tax, weight/distance charges, en-route charges, and flight segment charges, have been proposed to address these concerns, but each option has its own advantages and disadvantages, and the best approach will depend on the specific goals and priorities of the FAA and the aviation industry.

The effort was initiated in response to a 1993 report by the Institute of Medicine, which found that an estimated 60,000 military personnel participated in tests of mustard agents and lewisite. The DOD has identified approximately 5,842 servicemembers and 350 civilians who may have been exposed to these substances. However, the effort has been hampered by a lack of clear objectives, scope of work, and information needs.
* *The DOD's current effort lacks transparency, as it has not worked with veterans or veterans' service organizations and has not kept Congress and the public informed about the status of its efforts. The DOD has also not taken any actions to notify civilians who have been identified as having been potentially exposed. The lack of transparency has led to a lack of trust among veterans and veterans' service organizations.
* *The DOD has inconsistently transmitted information about identified servicemembers to the Department of Veterans Affairs (VA). The VA has not used all available resources to obtain contact information for servicemembers who were identified as having been potentially exposed. The VA has not regularly used the Internal Revenue Service's information or the Social Security Administration's death index to obtain contact information. As a result, the VA has been unable to notify all veterans who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances.
* *The DOD's contractor has not fully leveraged the work of other entities that have previously identified exposed individuals. The contractor has not visited repository sites to ensure that the work is effectively and efficiently meeting the task order's objectives. The contractor has not regularly evaluated the effectiveness or efficiency of its work. The contractor has also not taken any actions to notify civilians who have been identified as having been potentially exposed.
* *The DOD's effort has been hampered by a lack of clear leadership, inadequate internal controls, a shortage of personnel, and a lack of defined roles and responsibilities. The position responsible for overseeing the contractor's efforts has changed multiple times, and the contractor has had to work with different individuals. The DOD has not established a clear plan for identifying and notifying individuals who were potentially exposed to chemical or biological substances.

* The US government has been working to combat firearms trafficking to Mexico, with a focus on tracing firearms seized in Mexico and identifying their origin in the US.
* The Bureau of Alcohol, Tobacco, Firearms and Explosives (ATF) has been leading the effort, using its eTrace system to track firearms and identify their point of origin.
* The ATF has also been working with Mexican law enforcement agencies to provide training and equipment to help them combat firearms trafficking.
* However, there have been challenges in the collaboration, including corruption among some Mexican officials and frequent turnover in personnel.
* The Mexican government has also been working to combat firearms trafficking, with a focus on centralizing access to the eTrace system and consolidating law enforcement efforts.
* Despite these challenges, there are signs of progress, including the resumption of joint meetings between US and Mexican law enforcement agencies and increased cooperation on firearms trafficking cases.
* The US government is also working to improve its own internal coordination and communication on firearms trafficking, including through the use of a new interagency working group.

* *The National Criminal History Improvement Program (NCHIP) is a federal program that aims to improve the quality, completeness, and accessibility of criminal history records across the United States. The program provides grants to states to upgrade their criminal history record systems and make them compatible with national data systems. Since its inception in 1995, NCHIP has provided over $438 million in federal grants to states.
* *The program has made significant progress in automating criminal history records and making them accessible nationally. States have used NCHIP funds to upgrade their systems, improve data quality, and increase the number of records available for national searches. As a result, the percentage of automated criminal history records has increased from 79% in 1993 to 89% in 2001.
* *Despite progress, there are still challenges in automating and accessing certain types of records, such as domestic violence misdemeanor convictions and mental health records. States have made efforts to improve access to these records, but federal law and privacy concerns have hindered progress. The FBI's strategy is to use the Denied Persons File in the NICS Index to track denied firearm purchases.
* *The demand for background checks is growing, driven by screening requirements for employment and other non-criminal justice purposes. The number of civil fingerprint submissions to the FBI has increased substantially in recent years, and the FBI expects millions of additional background checks annually. Homeland security concerns have also increased the demand for background checks.
* *Technology is not static, and periodic upgrades or replacements of automated systems are necessary to ensure their continued functionality. States have used NCHIP funds to purchase new equipment and upgrade their systems, and they advocate for steady or long-term funding streams to support these efforts.
* *The long-term goal of NCHIP is to establish a national infrastructure for facilitating the interstate exchange of criminal history and other relevant records. The program has made significant progress, but continued progress will require a partnering of federal, state, and local resources and long-term commitments from all governmental levels.

<summary>
• The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has been using incineration as a method to clean up hazardous waste sites, but there are concerns about the safety and effectiveness of this method. The EPA has not followed its own policy of having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators, and there is no formal mechanism to share lessons learned from site to site. The agency has also not implemented its guidance for having RCRA hazardous waste incinerator inspectors evaluate Superfund incinerators, including the development of a single document specifying site-specific operating requirements and procedures. This lack of oversight and information sharing has raised concerns about the safety and effectiveness of the incineration process.

• The EPA has used incineration at three Superfund sites: the Baird and McGuire site in Massachusetts, the Bayou Bonfouca/Southern Shipbuilding site in Louisiana, and the Times Beach site in Missouri. At each site, the incinerator has been equipped with safety features such as automatic waste feed cutoffs and emergency systems to prevent the release of hazardous emissions. The EPA has also implemented various monitoring and oversight measures, including continuous air monitoring and regular inspections by the U.S. Army Corps of Engineers and state officials. However, despite these measures, incidents have occurred at each site, including a power outage at the Times Beach site that caused the emergency system to fail.

<summary>

• The Securities and Exchange Commission (SEC) did not maintain effective internal control over financial reporting as of September 30, 2007, due to material weaknesses and significant deficiencies in its internal control processes. The material weakness was caused by a combination of control deficiencies in the period-end financial reporting process, disgorgements and penalties accounts receivable, accounting for transaction fee revenue, and preparing financial statement disclosures.

• The SEC's financial statements were fairly presented in all material respects for fiscal years 2007 and 2006, but the weaknesses in internal control may have affected the reliability of the financial information reported. The SEC's financial management system does not conform to the systems requirements of OMB Circular No. A-127, Financial Management Systems.

• The SEC's period-end financial reporting process is supported by a collection of automated systems that are not integrated or compatible with its general ledger system, requiring extensive manual and labor-intensive accounting procedures. The SEC's process for calculating its accounts receivable for disgorgements and penalties presents a high risk that significant errors could occur and not be detected.

• The SEC's financial reporting process lacks a documented timeline and process for completing the fiscal year 2007 financial statements and disclosures, including review of the disclosures. The SEC's cumbersome and complicated financial reporting process did not allow sufficient time for thorough and complete reviews of the disclosures.

• The SEC has not consistently implemented key information security controls to effectively safeguard the confidentiality, integrity, and availability of its financial and sensitive information and information systems. The SEC has not yet fully implemented its information security program, and the information that is processed, stored, and transmitted on its systems remains vulnerable.

• The SEC's property and equipment consists of general-purpose equipment used by the agency, capital improvements made to buildings leased by SEC for office space, and internal-use software development costs for projects in development and production. The SEC lacks a process that integrates controls over capitalizing and recording property and equipment purchases.

• The SEC's accounting for obligations and undelivered orders is not effective, and the agency lacks policies or internal controls to prevent recording of obligations that are not valid. The SEC's general ledger is not configured to properly post related entries, resulting in the need for routine correcting entries.

• The Food Stamp Program provides eligible low-income households with paper coupons or electronic benefits that can be redeemed for food in stores nationwide. The program is funded by the Food and Nutrition Service (FNS) and requires states to certify household eligibility and establish requirements for households to report changes in their circumstances. The program also has various options and waivers to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families.

• The Food Stamp Program has several options and waivers to increase program access and reduce the reporting burden on working families. For example, states can confer categorical eligibility for food stamps to households receiving certain TANF-funded services or benefits, and can exempt some or all vehicles from counting as assets in determining food stamp eligibility. Additionally, states can use reporting options and waivers to change the way households with earnings are required to report changes in their circumstances.

• The Food Stamp Program has a quality control system to monitor states' performance in accurately determining food stamp eligibility and calculating benefits. The system measures states' payment errors by drawing a statistical sample to determine whether participating households received the correct benefit amount. States are penalized if their payment error rate is higher than the national average, which was 8.9 percent in fiscal year 2000.

• The Food Stamp Program has several reporting options and waivers to reduce the reporting burden on working families. For example, states can use semiannual reporting, which allows households with earned income to report changes in their circumstances every 6 months instead of monthly. States can also use waivers to exempt certain households from reporting changes in their circumstances.

• The Food Stamp Program has several options and waivers to support working families, including the Transitional Benefit Alternative, which provides a fixed food stamp benefit to households leaving welfare for a certain period of time. The program also has a simplified program option, which allows states to merge the rules of the Food Stamp Program and the Temporary Assistance for Needy Families (TANF) program into a single set of requirements for households receiving both types of assistance.

ICE officers rely on formal and on-the-job training, guidance provided by supervisors, and guidance provided in field operational manuals to inform their decision making.
* ICE has not instituted a mechanism to ensure that legal developments are consistently disseminated to ICE officers across all field offices, which can lead to officers not receiving necessary legal guidance in a timely manner. Supervisors are responsible for reviewing and authorizing decisions made by officers, but ICE does not have a mechanism to analyze information specific to the exercise of discretion. ICE's inspection program is designed to determine whether field offices are complying with established policies and procedures, but it does not analyze information on officer decision making.

* Ground ambulance services are provided by a wide range of organizations, including for-profit, nonprofit, and government-based providers, which differ in their organizational structure, staffing, and revenue sources. Medicare payments for ambulance services are made up of two components: a service-level payment for the type of transport provided and a mileage payment. The mileage payment is determined by the number of miles traveled with a patient during an ambulance transport and the mileage base rate. The Medicare payment formula has been updated over time, with a 50% increase in the rural mileage rate in 2002.
* The cost of providing ground ambulance services varies greatly among providers, with a median cost per transport of $429 in 2010. The cost of providing ambulance services is influenced by factors such as the volume of transports, the mix of Medicare transports, and the level of government subsidies received. Providers with lower transport volumes tend to have higher costs per transport due to fixed costs for maintaining readiness. The cost of providing ambulance services is also influenced by the level of volunteer staff hours and the percentage of Medicare transports that are nonemergency.
* The Medicare margin, which is the difference between Medicare payments and costs per transport, varies greatly among providers. The median Medicare margin was 2% in 2010, but ranged from a negative 1% to 10%. The Medicare margin is influenced by the level of government subsidies received and the mix of Medicare transports. Providers with higher Medicare margins tend to have more financial resources to invest in their operations and may be more likely to provide high-quality services.
* The number of ambulance transports has increased by 33% from 2004 to 2010, with the largest increase in super-rural areas. The increase in ambulance transports is attributed to an increase in nonemergency transports, which rose by 59% from 2004 to 2010. The increase in ambulance transports is also influenced by changes in the demographic characteristics of Medicare beneficiaries, such as age, race, and sex. The increase in ambulance transports has led to an increase in Medicare payments for ambulance services, which has put pressure on the Medicare program to ensure that payments are targeted to the most needy areas.

• Ginnie Mae is a government-sponsored enterprise that securitizes government-backed mortgages, such as FHA and VA loans, and guarantees timely payment of principal and interest to investors. Ginnie Mae's mission is to expand affordable housing in America by linking capital markets to the nation's housing markets. The agency's guarantee of timely payment of principal and interest makes it an attractive option for investors.

• Ginnie Mae's primary product is mortgage-backed securities (MBS), which are backed by government-insured or guaranteed mortgages. The agency's MBS are traded on the secondary market, allowing investors to buy and sell them. Ginnie Mae's MBS are considered to be a low-risk investment, as they are backed by the full faith and credit of the US government.

• Ginnie Mae's market share of the MBS market has declined significantly over the past 20 years, from 54% in 1985 to 10% in 2004. This decline is due to the growth of the conventional MBS market and the increasing availability of private mortgage insurance. Despite this decline, Ginnie Mae remains the dominant player in the government-backed MBS market.

• Ginnie Mae's revenue comes from guarantee fees and commitment fees, which are paid by issuers of MBS. The agency's expenses include the cost of operating its programs, maintaining its data systems, and providing customer service. Ginnie Mae's excess revenue is invested in US government securities and reduces the federal budget deficit.

• Ginnie Mae faces challenges in responding to changes in the marketplace and meeting the needs of its stakeholders. The agency has taken steps to improve its products and services, including the development of new securitization products and the expansion of its Targeted Lending Initiative.

• Ginnie Mae's data systems are not always accurate and consistent, which can make it difficult for investors to assess prepayment risk. The agency is working to improve its data systems and provide better information to investors.

• Ginnie Mae's prepayment rates have historically been lower than those of conventional MBS, but have increased in recent years. The agency is working to improve its prepayment modeling and provide better information to investors.

• The Department of Defense (DOD) has made significant improvements to its controls to identify and prevent illegal and otherwise improper closed account adjustments, resulting in an 80% reduction in such adjustments during the first 6 months of fiscal year 2002. DOD has also implemented new policies and procedures to ensure that contract modifications do not result in illegal adjustments. However, the agency still has a long way to go in addressing its overall financial management and contract payment problems. The GAO has recommended that DOD continue to monitor its adjustments to ensure that any potential Antideficiency Act violations are promptly investigated and reported.

• The GAO has reviewed DFAS officials' corrective actions taken on 162 adjustments that were previously reported as $615 million of illegal or otherwise improper adjustments. The review found that DOD had reversed and corrected the adjustments, but the process created additional accounting errors that must now be researched and corrected. The GAO also identified and met with DFAS officials knowledgeable about each reversed adjustment and obtained documentation to show how adjustments were reversed or corrected in the accounting records.

• The GAO monitored DFAS Columbus' review of $291 million of the $1.9 billion of closed account adjustments DOD reportedly made during fiscal year 2001. The review found that 59% of the adjustments were either illegal or otherwise improper and should not have been made. The GAO analyzed documentation supporting DFAS's detailed summaries for each adjustment to determine the reason for the adjustment and whether it was valid.

• The GAO tested the CRS for two types of potentially illegal adjustments during a 6-month period. The test found that CRS had processed some closed account adjustments that resulted in moving a disbursement charge back to an appropriation that was canceled before the actual disbursement was made or forward to an appropriation that had not yet been enacted at the time the actual disbursement was made. The GAO met with responsible DFAS Columbus officials to discuss and resolve any transactions that were identified as violations.

• The GAO recommends that the Secretary of Defense direct the Under Secretary of Defense (Comptroller) to continue to monitor DOD's adjustments to ensure that any potential Antideficiency Act violations are promptly investigated and reported. The GAO also recommends that DOD continue to work to simplify accounting and contract payment allocation terms, modernize financial management systems, and improve the systems' adherence to basic accounting requirements.

However, the departments still face significant challenges in achieving their long-term goals, including the development of a two-way exchange of computable patient medical records.
• The VA and DOD have established a joint project management structure and have made progress in developing a project management plan, but the plan lacks detail on specific tasks and time frames, and security policy has not yet been finalized. The departments also face challenges in developing an electronic interface that will enable the exchange of computable patient medical records, including the need to convert health information in VA's Health Data Repository into an interoperable format. Despite these challenges, the VA and DOD are committed to achieving their long-term goals and are working to overcome the obstacles that stand in their way.

<summary>

• The Internal Revenue Manual (IRM) defines the desired outcome of an income tax audit as the determination of the correct taxable income and tax liability of the person or entity under audit. The auditor has a responsibility to conduct a quality audit, which is defined by nine audit standards. These standards address issues such as the scope, techniques, technical conclusions, reports, and time management of an audit.

• The audit standards have evolved since the 1960s and have one or more key elements that must be met. The key elements are used to measure the quality of the audit and are used to identify areas for improvement.

• The audit workpapers are a critical component of the audit process and provide documentation of the procedures applied, tests performed, and evidence gathered during the audit. The workpapers also provide support for the auditor's conclusions and are used by third-party reviewers to assess the quality of the audit.

• The IRM requires that audit workpapers meet certain standards, including fully disclosing the audit trail and techniques used, being clear, concise, legible, and organized, and ensuring that tax adjustments recorded in the workpapers agree with IRS Forms 4318 or 4700 and the audit report.

• The Examination Quality Measurement System (EQMS) is used by the IRS to measure the quality of closed audits against the nine audit standards. The EQMS uses key element pass rates to measure the quality of the audit.

• The key element pass rate is the percentage of audits that demonstrate the characteristics defined by the key element. The pass rate is used to identify areas for improvement and to establish a baseline for improvement.

• The IRS uses the EQMS to identify areas for improvement and to make changes to the audit process. The EQMS also provides a way to measure the effectiveness of changes made to the audit process.

• The IRS has found that the quality of audit workpapers has been a problem in the past. The EQMS has identified that IRS auditors have not always met the key elements of the workpaper standard.

• The IRS is currently drafting changes to the IRM to improve the quality of audit workpapers. The changes will require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers.

• The GAO recommends that the IRS Commissioner require audit supervisors to document their review of audit workpapers as a control over the quality of audits and the associated workpapers.

<summary>

* *The State Department's (State) Antiterrorism Assistance (ATA) program was authorized in 1983 to enhance the antiterrorism skills of friendly countries by providing training and equipment. The program's purpose is to deter and counter terrorism, strengthen bilateral ties, and increase respect for human rights.
* *ATA offers training courses and equipment to partner nations, with a focus on enhancing critical counterterrorism capabilities, such as crisis management and response, cyberterrorism, and dignitary protection.
* *The program's largest recipient of funding is the Coordinator for Counterterrorism (S/CT), which is responsible for overseeing the program and providing policy guidance.
* *S/CT has a tiered list of countries based on their counterterrorism needs and the level of diplomatic and political engagement with the United States.
* *The State Department's Bureau of Diplomatic Security (DS/T/ATA) is responsible for implementing the program and providing training and equipment to partner nations.
* *DS/T/ATA conducts needs assessments and program reviews to determine the types of assistance to provide to partner nations, but these assessments are not consistently used to guide program decisions.
* *The program lacks clear measures of sustainability, and there is no systematic process for assessing the sustainability of partner nations' counterterrorism capabilities.
* *The State Department has not complied with a congressional mandate to report on U.S. international counterterrorism assistance since 1996, and its annual reports on ATA have contained inaccurate data and lacked systematic assessments of program performance.
* *The Government Accountability Office (GAO) has recommended that the State Department revise its internal guidance, improve the needs assessment and program review process, and establish clearer measures of sustainability to improve the effectiveness of the ATA program.

<summary>

* *The U.S. bankruptcy system is designed to provide a framework for resolving the financial affairs of individuals and businesses that are unable to pay their debts. The Bankruptcy Code is a federal law that provides for the reorganization or liquidation of a debtor's assets to pay off creditors.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code has several chapters that provide for different types of bankruptcy proceedings, including Chapter 7, which is liquidation, and Chapter 11, which is reorganization. Chapter 11 allows a debtor to restructure its debt and continue operating its business.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code also provides for the appointment of a trustee to oversee the bankruptcy proceedings and manage the debtor's assets. The trustee is responsible for collecting and selling the debtor's assets, paying off creditors, and distributing any remaining funds to the debtor.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code also provides for the automatic stay, which is a court order that stops most collection activities against the debtor. The automatic stay gives the debtor a temporary reprieve from creditor harassment and allows the debtor to focus on reorganizing its finances.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code also provides for the discharge, which is a court order that releases the debtor from personal liability for certain debts. The discharge is usually granted after the debtor has completed the bankruptcy proceedings and has made all required payments to creditors.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code also provides for the reorganization plan, which is a plan that outlines how the debtor will restructure its debt and pay off creditors. The reorganization plan must be approved by the bankruptcy court and must be in the best interests of the creditors.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code also provides for the liquidation, which is the process of selling the debtor's assets to pay off creditors. The liquidation is usually the last resort for debtors who are unable to reorganize their debt.*

* *The Bankruptcy Code is administered by the U.S. Bankruptcy Courts, which are federal courts that have jurisdiction over bankruptcy cases. The Bankruptcy Courts are responsible for interpreting the Bankruptcy Code and making decisions about bankruptcy cases.*

* *The electricity industry is composed of four distinct functions: generation, transmission, distribution, and system operations. The industry relies heavily on information technology (IT) systems and networks, making it vulnerable to cyber-based threats.*
* *The industry has taken steps to update the grid by integrating new technologies and IT systems, but there are still challenges to be addressed, such as monitoring the implementation of voluntary cybersecurity standards and clarifying regulatory responsibilities.*
* *The Federal Energy Regulatory Commission (FERC) has a role in overseeing the industry, but it has not developed an approach to monitor the implementation of voluntary smart grid standards and has not taken steps to determine the extent to which utilities and manufacturers are following these standards.*
* *The National Institute of Standards and Technology (NIST) has developed cybersecurity standards for smart grid systems, but the industry lacks an effective mechanism to disclose information about cybersecurity vulnerabilities, incidents, threats, lessons learned, and best practices.*
* *The industry also lacks a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity, with a focus on compliance with regulatory requirements rather than achieving effective cybersecurity. This can be addressed by taking a comprehensive approach to cybersecurity and ensuring that smart grid systems have built-in security features.*
* *The Department of Homeland Security (DHS) has a role in protecting the industry, but the industry lacks metrics for evaluating cybersecurity, making it difficult to determine the effectiveness of cybersecurity investments and make informed decisions.*

</summary>

<summary>

• The federal government faces a high risk of mission-critical skills gaps, which can impede its ability to cost-effectively serve the public and achieve results. The gaps are due to insufficient numbers of people or inadequate skills and abilities to accomplish mission-critical work. The problem is exacerbated by budget and long-term fiscal pressures, changing nature of federal work, and a potential wave of employee retirements.

• The federal compensation system does not align well with modern compensation principles, where pay decisions are based on skills, knowledge, and performance. The system rewards length of service rather than individual performance and contributions, and provides automatic annual pay increases to all employees, including poor performers. This can lead to a lack of motivation and retention of high-performing employees.

• The GS classification system is outdated and does not keep pace with the government's evolving requirements. The system is based on a position's duties, responsibilities, and difficulty, but has not been updated to reflect the highly skilled and specialized nature of modern federal work. This can lead to inaccurate pay and promotion decisions.

• Effective performance management is critical to addressing poor performance and retaining high-performing employees. However, the federal government has struggled to develop and implement effective performance management systems, which can lead to a lack of accountability and poor employee engagement. Good supervisors are key to the success of any performance management system.

• The federal government has a number of tools and flexibilities available to improve executive branch personnel management, but agencies must be held accountable for fully leveraging these resources. The government must also address the long-term fiscal challenges facing the nation and ongoing operational and accountability issues across government to ensure that it can attract, motivate, and retain a high-performing, agile workforce.

The services used these funds to support GWOT operations, but the DOD did not explicitly account for these funds in its budget.
* The DOD and the military services used various authorities to cover gaps between reported obligations and supplemental appropriations, including transferring funds from other accounts and reducing or deferring planned spending for peacetime operations. The Army transferred $3 billion from its working capital fund to cover its fiscal year 2004 gap, while the Air Force reduced its peacetime flying hours and deferred depot maintenance activities. The Navy canceled or deferred procurement actions and reduced its air operations and ship depot maintenance activities.

The Navy and Marine Corps did not forecast gaps in their GWOT obligations. The Army attributed its forecasted gap to higher fuel costs, support of its modular force initiative, and higher spending in the second half of the fiscal year.
* The Air Force attributed its forecasted gap to replenishing its Transportation Working Capital Fund and higher-than-anticipated end-strength levels. The Navy and Marine Corps did not forecast gaps in their GWOT obligations, with the Navy expecting to obligate additional funds to support its operations in Iraq and Afghanistan. The Air Force reduced its peacetime flying hours and deferred depot maintenance activities.

However, Treasury officials and others have identified reducing the number of unnecessary foreclosures as critical to the economic recovery. Treasury plans to track performance measures of the number of HAMP modifications, the redefault rate, and the change in average borrower payments to evaluate the program.

* The Food and Drug Administration (FDA) and the U.S. Department of Agriculture (USDA) are responsible for ensuring the safety of the food supply, but they lack the authority to regulate food security.
* The FDA and USDA have issued voluntary guidelines for food processors to implement security measures to prevent deliberate contamination, but they do not collect information on industry's implementation of these measures.
* The agencies believe they lack the authority to mandate security measures and are concerned that sharing information on industry's security efforts could compromise national security.
* The FDA and USDA have conducted risk assessments, but they do not have information on industry's security efforts to assess the risk of deliberate contamination.
* The agencies have instructed their field inspectors to discuss food security with facility personnel, but they do not document these discussions or require facilities to implement specific security measures.
* The food industry is concerned about sharing sensitive information with federal agencies due to the potential for public disclosure under the Freedom of Information Act.
* The industry has implemented various security measures, including risk assessments, background checks, and access controls, but the extent to which these measures are implemented is unknown.
* The FDA and USDA have provided training to some of their field inspectors on food security, but more training is needed to ensure that inspectors are knowledgeable about food security issues.
* The government is considering seeking additional authority from Congress to regulate food security, but the extent to which this will occur is unclear.

* The baby boomer generation will start turning 65 in 2011 and will continue to age, leading to a significant increase in the number of older workers in the labor force. This will lead to a change in the ratio of workers to retirees, with the number of workers per retiree decreasing from 3.3 in 2000 to 2.1 by 2030. As a result, the aged dependency ratio will increase, making it more challenging for younger workers to support the retired population.
* The number of older workers will grow rapidly over the next two decades, with the percentage of workers over 55 increasing from 13% in 2000 to 20% by 2025. This growth will be driven by the aging of the baby boomer generation and an increase in labor force participation among older workers. By 2025, one out of every five workers will be over 55.
* Older workers will become a larger proportion of the workforce, with the number of workers over 65 increasing from 4.4 million in 2000 to 10.4 million by 2025. This growth will be driven by the aging of the baby boomer generation and an increase in labor force participation among older workers.
* The composition of the older workforce will shift towards white-collar and service occupations, with fewer workers in blue-collar and production occupations. This shift will be driven by the increasing demand for skilled workers and the decreasing demand for unskilled labor.
* Older workers will continue to make gains in their earnings, with median earnings increasing by 9% for workers aged 55-64 and 19% for workers aged 65-74 between 1989 and 1999. This growth will be driven by an increase in the number of older workers in higher-paying occupations and an increase in the number of older workers working full-time.
* Older workers will be less likely to lose their jobs, with 39% of workers aged 55-74 who lost their jobs not being re-employed compared to 19% of workers aged 40-54. This difference will be driven by the fact that older workers are more likely to have longer tenures and be in more senior positions.
* Flexible employment arrangements, such as part-time or part-year work, will become more common among older workers. These arrangements will be driven by the desire of older workers to continue working but with reduced hours, and the need of employers to retain experienced workers.
